English title: Wuhan pneumonia 50 days, all the Chinese people are to bear the cost of the media death January 27

English content:
Original    
Written by Hou Siyin and   Yang Zhijie  
China News Weekly

For patients with end-stage cancer, the consequence of "temporary expropriation" is forced discharge, no medicine, no infusion, and only going home
Liu Jun's (pseudonym) relative is a patient with end-stage gastric cancer, who was receiving hospice care in Wuhan Guangfa Cancer Hospital.
At 7: 50 pm on February 5, they suddenly received a notice that the hospital was temporarily requisitioned, and all the wards were used to accept and treat patients with fever suspected of COVID-19.
Liu Jun's relative and at least 15 other patients with end-stage cancer were all required to be discharged from hospital.
10 minutes later, the patient was stopped and given half of the nutrient solution, and was carried out from the hospital.
3 days later, the medical team of Zhoukou City, Henan Province took over the secondary specialized hospital.
As a matter of fact, this hospital is not among the five designated hospitals with COVID-19 announced by Wuhan, and it was also stated as "temporary requisition" in official news reports.
However, for patients with end-stage cancer, the consequence of "temporary expropriation" is forced discharge, no medicine, no infusion, and only going home
Miao Xiaohui, a Shanghai public health clinical consultant, told China News Weekly that some hospitals are understaffed, doctors were afraid, and patients were afraid to go to hospitals.
However, it is an urgent problem for patients with chronic diseases and malignant tumors such as diabetes, hypertension and coronary heart disease to receive reexamination and effective treatment. The government should consider how to make these patients see doctor.
With the development of the epidemic situation, he was worried that patients with chronic diseases will face greater difficulties.
The following is Liu Jun's dictation.
In this extraordinary period, the appeal to fight against the COVID-19 epidemic was overwhelming, while the calls of these ordinary chronic patients and their families are rarely heard:
My relative is 59 years old and suffers from end-stage gastric cancer. The whole stomach was removed 4 years ago and relapsed at the end of last year.
She also has severe intestinal obstruction, because after gastrectomy, she could only eat by intestinal tract, so after intestinal obstruction, her body began to deteriorate obviously. In December last year, she couldn't swallow anything, and once she ate it, she would spit it out.
After many attempts, the doctor felt that chemotherapy had no effect on her, and other treatments were unnecessary.
But she couldn't eat, and we couldn't be taken care at home, so after many inquiries, they found Wuhan Guangfa Cancer Hospital.
This is a second-class oncology hospital, and it is also the designated hospital for severe cancer outpatient service in Wuhan. It mainly treats some patients with severe cancer and provides special hospice care services.
Because normal hospitals generally dissuaded such patients who did not need further treatment, we searched around and found that this hospital was in good condition at that time, and every patient was in a single room, so we sent her to hospital on January 17.
Wuhan was locked down on January 23, which didn't have much impact on us at the beginning. Because this hospital is specialized in oncology, no new patients were accepted after the lockdown, leaving only critically ill patients.
The whole hospital was basically in a semi-lockdown state, and all the entrances and exits were controlled, so that only family members can enter, and we wore masks every time.
On February 2, we suddenly received a notice from the hospital that the hospital might be requisitioned to receive fever patients, and the whole building where we are located would be vacated, and all the original patients would be moved to another new building.
So from this day on, all the medical personnel and patients began to do the work of ward transfer, and the medical personnel worked very hard and did not rest for 24 hours.
At about 6 o'clock on the evening of February 5, we went to deliver things, and the doctor ran out in a hurry, saying that they had just received the notice and would move soon, and all the patients with fever would have to live in within 2 or 3 hours.
Then all the patients' families were called to the hospital urgently. Like other families, we began to move things to the new ward of another building.
After arriving at the new ward, the head nurse answered a phone call less than 5 minutes after cleaning the room. She collapsed at that time, saying that the superior had received a notice asking all our patients to leave the hospital immediately and go home, and the whole hospital was requisitioned. It was around 7: 50 pm.
It was chaotic at that time, and many patients had not moved well.
There were about 15 patients receiving hospice care like my relatives, all of whom were middle-aged and elderly people.
When receiving the notice, everyone was shocked, and many people were scared. They didn't know when the fever patients would come, because the notice said they would come soon.
Our first reaction at that time was what to do next.
These patients are all hospice patients, and there was no other treatment. They just had nutrient solution every day to maintain their basic survival, and they couldn't get rice and water.
Therefore, after leaving the hospital, as long as I stop infusion, they had no means to treat themselves, and they could only die when going back home.
At that time, many patients, including us, raised the question of follow-up treatment. However, there was no oral explanation on how to treat the patients, how to care at home and how to relieve their pain.
I asked if at least some medicines could be provided, but it couldn’t.

I could see that the doctors and nurses really wanted to help, but they really couldn't help it, and they were devastated because they didn't have any psychological preparation or protective facilities for patients who will receive fever.
As a specialized hospital, I have never received fever patients before.
After the epidemic situation in Wuhan became serious, these medical personnel only wore masks. When they moved to the ward, only a few personnel wore protective clothing, but they were rather simple and crude.
Later, we were the first to decide to leave. At that time, before the nutrient solution was finished, the infusion stopped on the spot and the patient was carried away. It was 8 o'clock in the evening when we left the hospital.
Because we didn't want the old man to toss about, and we didn't want to make a noise in front of her.
At that time, some medical personnel told us that the hospital would be completely closed soon. If we didn't leave now, no one could leave when the fever patient came.
When we left, other patients were still negotiating with the hospital. As far as I know, these people were forced to move out later.
I learned that the whole cancer hospital was taken over by a medical team in Zhoukou City, Henan Province, so I wanted to contact the doctors and nurses before, but I couldn't get in touch.
I read the news report and found that Zhoukou Medical Team entered Wuhan Guangfa Cancer Hospital on the morning of February 8, that is, the 3rd day after we were forced to leave the hospital.
After being forced to leave the hospital, I began to find a way.
First, I found out from my friends in Wuhan Union Hospital that all the wards in Union Hospital were full, and now their medical personnel were limited, so there were not many patients like us who need treatment.
Later, I went to the People's Liberation Army No.161 Hospital, and they said that for any patient in hospitals in Wuhan, it was necessary to first rule out the suspected patients with COVID-19, such as taking chest radiographs, taking blood to see white blood cells, and whether there were fever symptoms, etc., and then they could accept them after exclusion, only if they have beds.
The oncology department of No.161 Hospital has been shut down, and there was no available bed, so they couldn’t be accepted.
A few days ago, I contacted Caidian district People's Hospital, and the other party said they could accept it, but they also had fever patients there, so we could be hospitalized if we wanted to.
Because Caidian Hospital is outside the lockdown Wuhan, we haven't had the road pass, so we couldn’t go there.
The person who locked the road told us to go to the community office to solve this problem.
I also contacted 2 private hospitals, which provided hospice care services, but they all said that although they had beds, they no longer accepted new patients.
Later, I learned through some friends that it was common in Wuhan that patients with end-stage cancer have no way to seek treatment.
My friend's family was in Hebei, and had died in a similar situation.
If hospitalization didn’t work, we wondered if we can get some nutrient solution by ourselves or find a doctor to inject it at home.
However, it was later discovered that drugs such as nutrient solution, tranquilization, anesthesia and pain relief were all controlled drugs in hospitals, which could only be prescribed by doctors after hospitalization.
Now, even if such drugs can be prescribed, it was very difficult for nurses to give injections when they could not be hospitalized.
Because of several medical disputes, Wuhan stopped all the "home care" services in 2019. Doctors were forbidden to go to residents' homes without permission in major hospitals, including nurses' nursing.
But now, after all, it was a special case. I hoped the hospital can find a more feasible plan considering our patients.
After my relatives came home, they left the nutrient solution, and became weaker. There were new inflammations in the body and no anti-inflammatory drugs. The patients became more and more painful, and they kept crying for pain, moaning all the time, and their sanity gradually began to become unconscious, only instinctive reaction, shouting for pain or losing their temper.
Now, the frequency and times of her screaming has become less and less, because she was getting weaker and weaker.
From the evening of February 5 to now, she has not eaten at all and has not slept at all.
We looked very worried and uncomfortable.
If there was any way to relieve the pain of our loved ones even for a day or a half, we would feel a little comfort in our hearts.
But whatever, we wouldn’t give up.
(On February 13, shortly after Liu Jun was interviewed by China News Weekly, the reporter learned that his family had passed away.
In his reply, he said: I sincerely hope that your report can help more families and people! )
(This article exclusively contributes to Tencent platform, which cannot be reproduced without authorization)
Editor on duty: Shi Ruoxiao

English content: On March 10, the Chinese “Portrait Magazine” posted an article titled “The Whistle-Distributor”, which interviewed a female doctor from Wuhan. Late last year, she was the first doctor that shared the report on "Wuhan Pneumonia" with other doctors (including Li Wenliang), who later used the report to warn others about the virus. That was why she called herself not so much a “whistle-blower” as a “whistle-distributor”.  “The tragedy could’ve been avoided. If I had known, I would’ve spread the news as much as possible”, the doctor said in the interview. Not only did the post receive numerous views, but the doctor’s remarks were also shared widely on the Internet. As a result, the post was censored and deleted on Portrait’s official Weibo account.  But that was when something interesting happened: Many official social media accounts, independent media, and other websites shared the censored post, which soon went viral on the Internet.
English title: Story of “Whistle-Distributor” Causes Viral Phenomenon in China
原文標題: “发哨人”引发的中国网络奇观

English title: "A Battle Against Epidemic: China Combating Covid-19 in 2020" Will be Published Soon.
原文標題: 《大国战“疫”》近期出版

English content:
The recently published “A Battle Against Epidemic: China Combating Covid-19 in 2020” was written under the guidance of the Propaganda Department and State Council Information Office, and co-published by China Intercontinental Press and People's Publishing House.

The book is a compilation of carefully chosen articles from over two million words written in mainstream media reports, collectively reflecting President Xi Jinping’s commitment to the people, his sense of mission, far-reaching strategic vision, and outstanding leadership as the leader of a great power. It also introduces a panoramic view of the different stages and development of China’s collective battle against the epidemic, and the epidemic’s positive and upward trend under the leadership of the CCP led by President Xi. Also, it reflects the party’s leadership and clear advantages of China’s socialism with Chinese characteristics. In addition, it demonstrates the nation’s cooperative spirit with the international community, and its grand efforts in working together to maintain global and regional public health security.

English content: Author: Duanmu give Hong Source: Duanmu special incense I subscribe to the "Global Times" public num
English title: How much information was leaked in a self-censored article in the Global Times?
原文標題: 《环球时报》自删的一篇文章里透漏了多少信息？

English content:
"At first, it was Mr. Hu’s originality and eloquence that made me decide to subscribe to Global Times’ public account. Yesterday, to my surprise, the account proved to be more valuable than I’d thought after its release of the unbiased news report “Confession of Medical Staff from Wuhan Central Hospital: The Epidemic Is a ‘Demon-Revealing Mirror.’” However, for some unknown reason, the article has been deleted by the account. Fortunately, I’ve found it again on Sina, and before I tell you exactly how many “shameful” facts are revealed by the article, you should know that I believe it to be authentic and unbiased because it was written by a Global Times reporter who actually visited Wuhan Central Hospital and interviewed the medical staff.

The first message: Dr. Liu Jie from Wuhan Central Hospital said, “A lot of my colleagues have expressed their wish to resign once the epidemic was over. The epidemic has completely altered our attitude towards life and work; seeing the death of our colleagues and the helplessness of patients, we were defeated by the harsh reality again and again no matter how much we wanted to save lives.

What kind of “harsh reality” was she referring to?

The second message: According to Wuhan Central Hospital’s Dr. Tao Jun, who has been in practice for over 20 years, on December 28 and 29, 2019, Wuhan Central Hospital Houhu Branch admitted 4 patients with travel history to Huanan Seafood Market…On December 30, one of the patients’ diagnosis using the next-generation sequencing of BALF (bronchoalveolar lavage fluid) indicated a highly probable SARS infection, and the news spread quickly at Wuhan Central Hospital. When Tao Jun heard about the patient’s diagnosis, he felt that the catastrophe that took place 17 years ago was about to repeat itself… 
"
English title: How Much Was Revealed in the Article that Global Times Deleted?
原文標題: 《環球時報》自刪的一篇文章裡透漏了多少資訊？

English content:
The person who handed out the whistle — the warning of coronavirus (COVID-19)
This translation is made by COVID-19 Asia Observer, and its link is https://medium.com/@covid19asia/how-did-the-coronavirus-covid-19-outbreak-start-in-wuhan-china-5c5b0b270710
Please follow the instruction on Common Creative License and Copy Rights of the above webpage. 

 “If all these doctors received a timely reminder, maybe this day would have never arrived.” Ai Fen

On December 30th, 2019, Ai Fen received a virus detection report regarding a patient with unknown pneumonia. She circled the words “SARS coronavirus” in red. When asked by one of her university peers, she took a photo of this report and sent it to this fellow doctor. The same night, this report was shared throughout the entire circle of doctors in Wuhan. Those who forwarded the reports include the eight doctors who were investigated by the police for “spreading rumours.”

Ai Fen was identified as the original author of the report and was unprecedentedly and sharply reprimanded by the hospital disciplinary committee for spreading rumours as a professional.

According to some previous news reports, Ai Fen, when she surfaced, was described as “another female doctor who has been warned”.

Some people called her a whistleblower, but Ai Fen has corrected this statement — she is not a whistleblower, but the person who handed out the whistle.

    This is the second interview article of “Wuhan Doctor”series in a Chinese magazine issue, 人物 (Renwu or People). March, 2020.

    Aurthor｜龚菁琦 Guon JinQi ; Editor｜金石 Jin Shi ; Photograhy｜尹夕远 Yen XiYuan

It was 5am on March 1st when I received the text from Ai Fen, the Director of the Emergency Department (ER) of Wuhan Central Hospital, who agreed to the interview. Approximately half an hour later, 5:32 am, her peer Jiang Xueqing, the Director of Thyroid and Breast Surgery, passed away from the novel coronavirus, now known as COVID-19. Two days later, the deputy director of Ophthalmology of the hospital, Mei Zhongming, passed away. Mei and Li Wenliang were in the same department.

(Dr. Li Wenliang was one of the eight whistleblowers of coronavirus who died on February 7th, 2020. Dr. Jian Xueqing has worked in the Wuhan Central Hospital for thirty years. He was known as the warm doctor with a soft voice).

As of March 9th, 2020, four medical staff from the Wuhan Central Hospital have passed away from COVID-19. Since the outbreak, this hospital, just a few kilometers away from the Huanan Seafood Market, has become one of the most infected hospitals in Wuhan City. According to media reports, more than 200 people in Wuhan Central hospital were infected, including three vice presidents and multiple functional department directors. Moreover, several sectional directors are currently using extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) to maintain their health.

Wuhan Central Hospital, the largest grade A hospital (first class hospital) in central Wuhan is overshadowed by death. A doctor told 人物 (Renwu or People), almost no one spoke in the hospital, but all mourned and discussed in private.

The tragedy of the coronavirus had a chance to be avoided. On December 30th, 2019, Ai Fen received a virus detection report regarding a patient with unknown pneumonia. She circled the words “SARS coronavirus” in red. When Ai Fen was asked by one of her university peers, she took a photo of this report and sent it to this fellow doctor. The same night, this report was shared throughout the entire circle of doctors in Wuhan. Those who forwarded the reports include the eight doctors who were investigated by the police for “spreading rumours.”

Ai Fen was identified as the original author of the report and was unprecedentedly and sharply reprimanded by the hospital disciplinary committee for spreading rumours as a professional.

In the afternoon of March 2nd, Ai Fen agreed to have an interview with People in the Nanjing Road District of Wuhan Central Hospital. She sat in the emergency room office alone. The emergency department, which used to admit more than 1,500 patients a day, is now quiet. Only one homeless person lied there in the emergency hall.

According to some previous news reports, Ai Fen, when she surfaced, was described as “another female doctor who has been warned”. Some people called her a whistleblower, but Ai Fen has corrected this statement— she is not a whistleblower, but the person who handed out the whistle. During the interview with People, Ai Fen mentioned the word “regret” multiple times. She regretted not being able to continue blowing the whistle after the “disciplinary discussion”, especially towards her peers who had passed away. “Had I known what would happen today, I would not care about all the reprimands and criticisms, and would speak up about it everywhere, right?”

What have Ai Fen and the Wuhan Central Hospital experienced in the past two months? Below is Ai Fen’s narrative.

The unprecedented rebuke (This is a translation of Ai Fen recounting the story in her own words)

On December 16, 2020, our Emergency Department at the Nanjing Road Branch of Wuhan Central Hospital admitted a patient. The patient had an unexplainable high fever, The medication didn’t work and the body temperature didn’t come down. On December 22nd, the patient was transferred to the respiratory department and a bronchoscopy was performed, so that his/her alveolar lavage fluid could be acquired. The sample was sent to an external institution for high-throughput sequencing. Later, the result was informed orally, stating that it is coronavirus. At that time, a colleague who managed the hospital beds whispered several times in my ear: “Director Ai, that person is reported to be infected with coronavirus”. It was only afterwards that we found out the patient had worked in the Huanan Seafood Market (The first accused community-infected location).

On December 27th, another patient arrived at our Nanjing Road Branch. The patient was the nephew of a doctor in our department. He was in his 40s. He did not have any preexisting illness; however, his lungs were messed up and his blood oxygen saturation value was only 90% (A healthy individual should be above 94%). The hospital treated him for almost 10 days without any improvement, and the patient was transferred to the respiratory department. He also received a bronchoscopy, and his alveolar lavage fluid was sent out for testing.

At noon on December 30th, my classmate at Tongji Hospital sent me a screenshot through WeChat, which said: “Don’t go to the Huanan Seafood Market, many people came out with high fever …”. He asked me if this message was true. At the time, I was looking at the CT scan of a patient with typical pulmonary infection. I sent my classmate an 11-seconds video recorded from the CT scan and told him that this came from a patient who was admitted to our emergency room this morning. He also came from the Huanan Seafood Market.

Just after 4 pm on December 30th, my colleague showed me a report that stated: SARS coronavirus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, 46 kinds of oral / respiratory colonization bacteria. I carefully and repeatedly read the report. One of the footnotes states: “SARS coronavirus is a positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus. The main transmission modes of the virus are short-range airborne transmission of expiratory droplets or indirect contact with expiratory droplets of infected patients. This is a special pneumonia that can be significantly contagious and can affect multiple organ systems. This is also known as atypical pneumonia”.

At that time, I broke out in a cold sweat. This is a terrifying thing. Normally, when a patient is admitted to the respiratory care unit, the respiratory department should report this case. However, to play it safe, I immediately called and reported the situation to the hospital’s public health department and the infectious disease department. At that time, the director of our respiratory department happened to pass by my door. He was once involved in the SARS crisis. I grabbed him and said: “We have a patient who was admitted to your department and we found out that he is infected with coronavirus”. He glanced and immediately said: “This is troublesome. I knew this would be very concerning”.

After calling the departments of the hospital, I also circulated this report to one of my classmates. I purposely circled the sentence “SARS coronavirus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, 46 types of oral/respiratory colonization bacteria” in red, to catch his attention. I also circulated the report in the doctor’s group chat to alert everyone to take precautions.

On the night of 30th December, the message was spread widely. The screenshot of the report with the red circle was everywhere. I found out later that the message doctor Li Wenliang (the famous whistleblower) passed around is the same screenshot. At that time, I smelled trouble. Around 10:20 pm, the hospital sent me a message, a notice from the city health committee. Essentially, it asked us to stop arbitrarily releasing information relating to the unknown pneumonia to avoid public panic. If panic is caused due to this information leakage, one should be held responsible.

I was very scared at the time. I immediately forwarded the message to my classmate. About an hour later, the hospital sent another notice, emphasizing again that this internal pneumonia-related information should not be shared publicly. One day later, at 11:46 pm on 1st of January, 2020, the head of the hospital disciplinary committee sent me a message. He asked me to visit the committee the next morning.

I couldn’t sleep that entire night. I was very worried and thought about this over and over again; yet I felt that there are always two sides to everything. Even if it caused adversity, it is not necessarily a bad thing to alert the medical staff in Wuhan to take precautions. Around eight o’clock the next morning, before I finished my shift, I was called immediately to the office.

In the meeting, I was subjected to an unprecedented and severe rebuke. The leader said: “We couldn’t raise our heads when we go out for meetings. You were directly criticized by another director. As the director of the emergency department of the Wuhan Central Hospital, you are a professional. How can you not have any principles and be so undisciplined to spread rumours?” These are his exact words. He wanted me to communicate verbally, either through face to face meeting or call one by one, to all 200+people in the department that we are not allowed to spread this pneumonia information via WeChat or SMS, “not even to our husbands”.
English title: The person who handed out the whistle — the warning of coronavirus (COVID-19)
原文標題: 发哨子的人

English content:
Dr. Li Wenliang, an ordinary ophthalmologist who became a tragic hero by revealing the truth during the Wuhan Covid-19 pandemic, has not been forgotten by the public. In the comment section of his Weibo, thousands of people write down diaries every day. On the night of June 19, some netizens found out that this comment section had been cleared. The protest suddenly became ubiquitous. Soon after, the comments are available to the public again. However, people found that the top comments are gone, that all the comments are arranged in a chronological order, that the date the "Wailing Wall" was posted is fixed on June 19, 2020, and that all comments posted before this day are blocked. As more and more netizens protested, the former comments were magically restored. As of this post, Sina Weibo did not give an explanation on this. Since Dr. Li Wenliang’s Weibo may be instructed to be deleted by the Internet censorship office at any time, China Digital Times has archived the netizens’ comments on Dr. Li Wenliang’s Weibo on a daily selection basis, which will be carried on before his Weibo account is shut down. See "Chinese Wailing Wall" for details.

We no longer need to introduce who Li Wenliang is. Since February 7, 2020, Dr. Li Wenliang has become a memory that has once lived vigorously, one that is not only of Li Wenliang's lover and parents, but also of the countless netizens.

No one would have expected that the last Weibo posted by Li Wenliang during his lifetime would become the "wailing wall" for the Chinese.

English content: Guangdong's first batch of medical staff supporting in Hubei sent a medical assistance request to the world on “The Lancet” on February 24. "Due to the severe shortage of local medical workers in Wuhan, we need more support. We here request for medical assistance from medical workers around the world. Please come to China and help us fight against the pandemic." The article wrote. This article was marked as correspondence, titled "Chinese medical staff request international medical assistance in fighting against COVID-19," and was published online on February 24 on "The Lancet". The authors are two medical staff supporting in Hubei who came respectively from the Department of Nursing, the Third Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University and the Department of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University. The article presents the obstacles arising from the shortage of supplies to the health work. For example, since the goggles are made of plastic and need to be washed and disinfected repeatedly, they have become increasingly rugged, and the wearers’ vision is a bit blurred. Many colleagues got rash on their hands due to frequent hand washing. Furthermore, since they need to wear N95 masks and multi-layer protective equipment for a long time, some nurses had pressure sores on their ears and forehead.
English title: 【Deleted】 Voice from frontline doctors: Urging for international support.

Yang Chen is waiting for notification.
He is waiting for “Order No.10” to bring the turning chance of his and his family destiny, he is the kin of a “Wuhan patient”.
The “Order No.10” which he expects was issued on February 2.
In accordance with the requirements of the "Order No.10", since the announcement date, the close contacts of fever patients with pneumonia symptoms and COVID-19 patients diagnosed by the fever clinic in the whole city will be sent to the centralized quarantine observation points by vehicles arranged by each district.
Before this, just like many Wuhan patients’ families, Yang Chen has experienced long-time and tough wait.
For a long time, suspected patients like his family were told by the hospital to quarantine at home because they could not be diagnosed.
The recurrence and aggravation of the disease is accompanied by the traffic control after Wuhan “lockdown”. These patients are going through the rush and suffering on the way to find a hospital for treatment.
On this way, some people have passed away.
However, the big Wuhan which connects with 9 provinces, is also a patient.
Covered with epidemic, for this city where happiness and sadness are repeatedly happening, its maintenance of basic city function highly ties to the destines of people who stay in this city.
Those who need to be cured are not only the patients, but also Wuhan and those who are tied to the fate of this city.
Changes and opportunities are getting closer and closer.
On the evening of February 3, Huoshenshan Hospital received and cured the 1st batch of patients with COVID-19.
The “Brother” of Huoshenshan Hospital would also receive and cure patients on February 6.
Although Yang Chen was told by the community hospital to continue to wait, and there was no new news about the admission bed, no one can deny that Wuhan is racing against time to solve the difficult problem of "receive and cure".
On February 3, the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee held another meeting. Under the host of General Secretary Xi, it was the second time in about half a month that the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee had a meeting to study and deploy to strengthen epidemic prevention and control.
The meeting pointed out that it is necessary to improve the national emergency management system and improve the ability to deal with urgent and dangerous tasks in view of the shortcomings and shortcomings exposed in the response to the epidemic.
Curing patients in Wuhan, all people are racing against time.
Solve the difficulty of receiving and curing.
On the morning of February 2, after fighting for 9 days and nights, Huoshenshan Hospital has formally completed and put into use, which can provide 1000 beds, 1400 medical personnel deployed by the military have been in place. In the evening of February 3, the first batch of patients with COVID-19 went in Huoshenshan Hospital.

On the afternoon of February 3, the reporter visited the listed Huoshenshan Hospital in Wuhan. The inside and outside of the hospital were extremely nervous and busy, and all the people in each shift were ready to receive and cure the 1st batch of patients.
The “Brother” of Huoshenshan Hospital would also formally receive and cure patients on February 6, which can provide 1500 beds.
On the same day when Huoshenshan Hospital was completed and put into use, the Order No.10 was issued, which required centralized quarantine of all suspected patients.
Wuhan epidemic, the opportunity suddenly appeared.
Before this, many people and families in this city had experienced a long ordeal and a test of life and death.
Dial 120 and queue up; Dial the community and queue up up; Looking for "Wuhan Neighborhood", this platform collapsed on January 25.
During the "long" waiting, there were more and more patients in Wuhan who took families as the unit. Some people had stayed up until the day when they had an available bed. At this time, one or two of his family members had been infected, and even the whole family has been infected, so they had to continue looking for beds.
When someone had the available bed, they became seriously ill and died in ICU ward on New Year's Day.
On the morning of February 2, a patient's family told the “China Business Journal” reporter: "The 89-year-old grandmother couldn't wait, fell down in the hospital corridor during queuing up, died on the second day of the New Year, and even had to queue up to the funeral home. And the body was still in the mortuary of the hospital."
Mrs. Dao was so sad for uncle’s family experience, that couldn't get up.
Finally, her 77-year-old uncle was admitted to the hospital on January 31, and her 46-year-old cousin was also seriously ill with high fever and difficulty breathing.
"Uncle has been diagnosed as Covid-19, and cousin was diagnosed by the hospital on February 1. Now there is no available bed."
Mrs. Dao's uncle lives in Guanlan Community, Baishazhou, Wuhan. Before Wuhan carried out large-scale and high-frequency prevention and control of Covid-19, he had a heart stent operation.
“It was assumed that he was infected when returning to hospital.”
Mrs. Dao memorized.
On January 23, uncle began to feel particularly unwell. On January 24, he went to Wuchang Hospital for CT and blood test, and was found that his lungs were infected and his condition was critical. The hospital issued an admission certificate, but there was no available bed.
Dial 120 and queue up; Dial the community and queue up; Looking for "Wuhan Neighborhood", this platform collapsed on January 25.
At this time, Mrs. Dao's cousin was taking care of her uncle, namely, the patient's son, while Mrs. Dao was helping to find available bed, made a phone call and asked for help from the outside world.

"We are crazy to dial the community, 120 and the mayor's hotline. On January 31, uncle finally lived in Wuchang Tianyou Hospital, but my cousin was infected during the process of taking care of my uncle. He had high fever for several days, on February 1 he was diagnosed by the hospital (referring to the diagnosis of Covid-19), and now I am looking for the available bed everywhere."
Mrs. Dao almost cried sadly.
Due to infection of the cousin and worrying about two patients without caring, his sister came back to take care, now his sister also had fever.
“Now in uncle's family, only aunt, who has been over 70-year-old, can take care of them, how the family is going on?"
Mrs. Dao didn’t want to talk any more, she hoped there could be the hospital with available ward, so that they can be cured soon.
He is still waiting, however, some families cannot wait any more.
“Dad and uncle live in grandma’s old house and quarantine, they haven't had fever yet.”
On the morning of February 2, Xiao Zhu told reporters that grandma's body still stayed in the mortuary of the hospital and had not been transferred to the funeral parlor.
There was a queue in funeral parlor.
Xiao Zhu, the junior student of university, was still being cold.
“There are still some foods at home, I won’t tell dad temporarily, if I don't have a fever.”
Xiao Zhu's grandmother died on January 26, the 2nd day of Chinese New Year. Xiao Zhu didn't want his father to worry about himself.
Xiao Zhu's grandmother, aged 89, had serious difficulty breathing due to lung infection. She finally went in the hospital in a shuttle bus arranged by the community on January 24. Before she could make a diagnosis, she didn't wait for an available bed. Her grandmother died in the corridor of Hankou Hospital on January 26.
“Dad and uncle were taking care of grandma, dad is 65-year-old, I also worry about him.
Several days ago, Xiao Zhu said when he accepted interview of this journal.
She was so scared, because her mum had passed away (not related to COVID-19) before, she was very worried about losing the kin again.
“Dad and uncle live in grandma’s old house and quarantine, they haven't had a fever yet.”
Xiao Zhu told a reporter on February 2.
Xiao Zhu wanted to go out to buy some cold medicine, but the place where she lives was a bit special. "I live opposite Hankou Railway Station, 800 meters away from it is the South China Seafood Wholesale Market, which is the hardest hit area, and there is no drugstore around.".
Liu Xiaoxuan has been fighting for 8 days at home, at this time she can only be awake for about 4 hours every day.
"I am very tired. I can't draw a picture to relieve it. I am tired in 5 minutes. When I am tired, I have to sleep."
At this time, she was in her own home in Wuchang, and her father was hospitalized in Wuchang West District Hospital, and the symptoms of dyspnea eased; her mother is getting better, quarantined in maiden residence in Hankou, and still coughing.
It is her husband who has been supporting all the logistical work of this family by Xiaoxuan's side, and has started to have a low fever at present.
It was Xiaoxuan's mother who fell ill at first. Her father began to cough in the process of taking care of her, and did not have a fever at first, but the cough turned into difficulty breathing.
After CT and blood test, her parents were orally diagnosed as Covid-19 by hospital doctors, and suffered from general weakness, difficulty breathing and inability to move.
Under such circumstances, Xiaoxuan didn't lose heart. She made a division of labor. Her husband was responsible for household disinfection and food supply, and she was responsible for going to the hospital with her parents, such as finding a hospital, registering and queuing.
In order to reduce the time for parents to be exposed to the cross-infection environment in hospital, Xiaoxuan usually queues by herself, and takes over her father or mother after the estimated time is almost up.
On January 25, Xiaoxuan was interviewed by our reporter. At that time, although it was very difficult and tired, her mother got better with the joint efforts of her whole family, which made Xiaoxuan not lose confidence.
"Not only must we ensure the nutrition of patients, but family members must also pay attention to eating and maintaining physical strength so as to fight the virus."
Xiao Zhu told reporter.
She also shared some nursing experiences on the Internet to encourage more patients and their families.
However, since January 26, there were something wrong with Xiaoxuan’s body, and she has had a fever for many days since then. At that time, she was still encouraging herself, taking medicine, eating, and keeping physical strength, and she was bound to get better. She was also very struggled, and did not want to go to the hospital or be cross-infected.
On February 2, Xiaoxuan, who had been fighting disease continuously at home, still insisted on taking medicine, but obviously felt uncomfortable in her lungs.
“Deep breathing is very hurt, but little breathing is OK.”
She told reporter.
She is preparing ID card for going to a doctor.
"The ID card is in mum’s home in Hankou, mum can't send it, and my husband can't go up and get it. Mom and dad got sick there."
She is also trying her friend's suggestions, such as Chinese medicine and massaging some acupoints, but some ideas make her stop insisting.
“Now, I am following my husband.”
She said, “I am sick, and may be infected while taking care of my parent. I was OK before, maybe I was healthy, but maybe because the virus has infiltrated without showing.”

Now I would like to remind my family members not to be careless when taking care of patients, even if necessary protection has been taken, the examination should be done as soon as possible. "
She said that what she wants to do most now is not to take medicine or injection, but to go to the hospital and get a definite diagnosis from the doctor.
Race against time
Centralized quarantine of suspected patients and admission of confirmed patients will change the fate of these families.
On the evening of February 2, the headquarter of prevention and control of pneumonia epidemic in COVID-19 of Wuhan held a special dispatching meeting, which forced centralized quarantine for four groups of people, namely fever patients who were diagnosed, suspected and unable to rule out new pneumonia and close contacts of confirmed patients, and effectively controlled the source of infection by requisitioning a number of private hospitals, hotels, gymnasiums and other places.
At present, Wuhan has requisitioned 27 medical institutions, including Wuhan Minsheng Otolaryngology Hospital and other private chain specialized hospitals, which can provide 2,183 beds for treating suspected cases with negative results for the first time.
On the evening of February 3, the video dispatch meeting of the headquarter of pneumonia epidemic prevention and control in COVID-19 of Wuhan revealed that Wuhan International Convention and Exhibition Center will be transformed into three "mobile cabin hospitals" with a total of 3,400 beds.
At 1 pm on February 3, the reporter of “China Business Journal” contacted Yang Chen, the family member of the patient who had asked for help before, to inquire about the progress.
Yang Chen told reporters: "The community mentioned to me Order No.10, saying that it will carry out relevant quarantine diagnosis and treatment according to the severity of the disease, but in terms of specific implementation, it just told me to wait."
A community worker in Qiaokou District of Wuhan told reporters that the current situation in Wuhan is mainly caused by the shortage of beds, and we have no choice but to listen to the government's arrangement.
As early as January 26, Yang Chen contacted our reporter and told him that grandpa and his father were both suspected patients in COVID-19, but they failed to stay in the hospital after trying their best.
"The designated hospital told us that the bed was full and could not be treated, so let's contact the community to report it.
However, the community asked us to go to designated hospitals directly.
In this way, it becomes an infinite loop. "
Yang Chen told reporters: "Because my family lives in Qiaokou District of Hankou, it is close to the South China Seafood Wholesales Market.
Before the Spring Festival in every year, family members come here to buy seafood.
In this year, grandpa went to buy seafood as usual, maybe he was infected with this virus due to this.”
Yang Chen mentioned that grandpa could not be diagnosed, and the whole family could not be quarantined as close contacts.
Tian Xiaoling, a native of Wuhan, is in the same situation as Yang Chen.
On January 30, Tian Xiaoling launched a social platform for help: "I have been in Shanghai all the time, and I was blocked outside. Only through my relatives did I know that my mother was infected with COVID-19, and my father began to lose physic strength.
They are all in their fifties and sixties, and they have not received effective treatment until now. "
On the afternoon of February 3, the reporter contacted Tian Xiaoling, who told the reporter that her mother had not been hospitalized successfully.
They would still wait.
Order No.10 races against time
Solve medical care warranty
Among the patients in Wuhan, there are a group of "special" patients, who are doctors and are infected in the process of treating patients. In any major public health incident, the protection of medical personnel is the most important link.
This is same with SARS 17 years ago, and the epidemic situation is still the same, now.
The government is also seeking the answer to this question.
There are only two paths, namely, reasonable arrangement of the work intensity of medical personnel and allocation of adequate and standard medical and protective materials.
By 20: 00 on February 2, a total of 57 medical teams and 6775 medical team members were assigned to 27 designated medical institutions in Wuhan.
Dr. Wang from Beijing, who supports the work of Tongji Hospital Sino-French Branch, told this reporter: "As soon as the new ward is opened, there will be a steady stream of heavy patients, and there are many patients, and the number of patients will continue to grow."
"One shift of us works 6 hours, wear protective clothing, can't eat or drink water in the ward, and need to wear diapers.
Wearing diapers is also for the convenience of leaving the hospital. All clothes can be destroyed to prevent infection. “
Dr. Wang said.
"After finishing the work, everyone's lining clothes are all soaked. In order to prevent infection, the central air conditioner can't be turned on in the ward, and there is no heating in Wuhan. It is very cold after taking off the protective clothing, and there is no condition to take a bath in the hospital.
In order to reduce the risk of infection, we think of some local methods, such as making shoe covers with garbage bags and tape. “
Dr. Wang said.
However, before all this turned around, many medical personnel were still infected in the process of diagnosis and treatment of the epidemic.
Tian Liwen is the head nurse in the quarantine ward of a ward in Central Hospital of Wuhan.
In an interview with “China Business Journal”, he said that the front line is very difficult, and everyone is working with a sense of responsibility.
The ward is mainly for patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19.
Tian Liwen said: "A large number of medical personnel in our hospital has collapsed. Now it has become the  surgeons and nurses who treat patients with respiratory diseases."
She introduced: "The whole hospital is now very saturated, so is our workload and the number of beds.
In fact, according to the standard process, if there are confirmed cases among colleagues around us, the medical personnel we have had close contact with should be quarantined for observation for 14 days. However, the hospital is short of medical personnel, and CT examination is still negative for those like us who are not infected or ill, so we should not be quarantined and stick to the front line. "
"A group of nurses in hospital has been exhausted, and a group of nurses asked for leave to rest.
Therefore, there is no way at present. If the subsequent support forces are rotated, we will probably stick to it all the time. "
Tian Liwen told reporters that the most anxious thing for everyone is actually this problem. "The nurses in our clinical department ask me every day: head nurse, when will someone come to take shift?"
"We have 4 or 5 colleagues who have been infected and then diagnosed. It is reasonable to say that we should be quarantined last week, but as far as the current situation is concerned, it seems that no one can really substitute them, and we all have to insist on going to work."
Tian Liwen said helplessly, "If medical personnel have symptoms such as fever, we have to take CT of the lungs, and then do nucleic acid testing. If it is diagnosed, it needs hospitalization and quarantine treatment. The hospitalization of medical staff in our hospital can now be guaranteed."
It is understood that at present, Central Hospital of Wuhan has taken over Wuhan Hankou Hospital, and some medical personnel have been urgently transferred from surgical departments to support it.
"Now the number of patients is too large, and the team of doctors and nurses from other places has come, but it is still far from enough, and patients can't be treated."
According to Tian Liwen’s introduction, doctors are now changing shifts every four hours, and nurses are not enough, so they need to change shifts every six hours.
"For example, I am from 8: 00 am to 2: 00 pm. I don't eat, drink or go to the toilet for 6 hours."
Regarding the process of receiving patients, Tian Liwen told reporters that patients receive and treat according to the standard procedures.
Besides ordinary patients who come to the fever clinic, they are usually screened in the community hospital where they are located first, and then if there are problems such as severe fever, they will be sent to the designated fever hospital clinic according to the procedure. Outpatient doctors will determine whether to treat them according to the screening criteria, and then they will do nucleic acid detection after admission.
As for the change of outpatient volume, Tian Liwen said that this is not easy to compare intuitively.
For example, in our comprehensive hospital, all diseases were treated, but now some wards in our hospital only treat suspected or confirmed patients.
"At present, it is okay. There is no special situation. Everyone is in short supply of protective materials every day. The hospital has been preparing for it and can basically meet it. At least it is sufficient when we go to work every day. It just means that sometimes the quality is better and sometimes the quality is worse."
Wuhan Jinyintan Hospital, as a professional hospital for the prevention and treatment of infectious diseases in Wuhan, was the first to receive the confirmed COVID-19 patients, and the first-line medical staff also adhered to it for the longest time. At present, only confirmed cases were treated.
A nurse in Wuhan Jinyintan Hospital, who asked not to be named, told the reporter that there were 8 people in a shift in the intensive care unit and 40 pieces of protective clothing were issued.
The admission and diagnosis of related cases are arranged by doctors, and nurses are not clear about the specific situation.
"Now basically, some suspected patients are referred by the community neighborhood committees and community hospitals where the patients are located, but many communities are not in place."
According to a family member of an infected nurse in Wuhan Jinyintan Hospital, she has not left the ICU yet, and it is not convenient to talk.
Under the communication of the family, the nurse indirectly declined the interview.
On the morning of February 2, the second batch of 6 infected medical staff were discharged from the Union Hospital affiliated to Huazhong University of Science and Technology.
According to CCTV.com, the clinical symptoms of the six infected medical personnel were effectively controlled after treatment, and they met the discharge standards after discussion by the expert group.
It is understood that up to now, 9 of the 15 infected medical personnel in Union Hospital have been cured and discharged, and 6 are still being treated in quarantine.
The reporter contacted Liu Xiang with effort, a medical staff who was still in quarantine treatment at Union Hospital.
According to his introduction, he is in good health at present.
"Still waiting for the last nucleic acid test, I can be discharged from the hospital if I am negative."
Regarding the specific treatment process and other information, the medical staff said: "There is discipline and cannot be interviewed."
On January 25, ByteDance announced that it would donate RMB 200 million to the China Red Cross Foundation, and set up the "China Red Cross Foundation ByteDance Medical Workers Humanitarian Relief Fund" to provide financial support for frontline medical workers who were diagnosed with pneumonia in COVID-19.
According to the reporter of China Business Journal, as of February 2, the fund has announced 6 batches and 57 recipients.
Most of the medical staff diagnosed with infection came from Wuhan Jinyintan Hospital, Union Hospital, Zhongnan Hospital and other medical units.
Among them, there were 22 doctors and nurses infected with Covid-19 in Wuhan Union Hospital, 7 confirmed medical personnel in Wuhan Red Cross Hospital, 6 confirmed medical personnel in Tongji Hospital and Zhongnan Hospital, and 5 confirmed medical personnel in Wuhan Hanyang Hospital.
Overcoming medical bottleneck?
The other side of "difficult receiving and curing" and "doctor-patient infection" is the extreme pressure on medical resources in Wuhan since the outbreak of the epidemic.
On February 1, a reporter from China Business Journal visited the fever clinic on the first floor of Tongji Emergency Center.
Outpatient hall is full of patients who come for infusion and oxygen inhalation, and the cough sounds one after another.
Due to the lack of beds, many patients bring their own folding beds and receive oxygen therapy in the aisles.
One day after that, Huoshenshan Hospital was completed, and the tenth order was issued. One day later, Huoshenshan Hospital began to receive patients.
For Wuhan, it almost uses space to exchange time.
Before that, facing the epidemic, the medical hospitals in Wuhan had already reached the limit.
"There are many patients in Tongji Hospital every day, and the flow of people is very large."
A patient who is seeing a doctor in Tongji Hospital told reporters.
"We mobilized all doctors to invest in the front line. Except physicians, infectious disease doctors, including surgeons and anesthesiologists, they all trained and let them all invest in the front line."
Wang Wei, Dean of Tongji Hospital, once introduced.
However, it is still difficult to meet the needs of overcrowded fever clinics.
"It's easy to cross-infect here. At present, my mother and I rent an apartment near Tongji Hospital, go to take IV every day, and come back after IV.
Basically, when we take injections, we also take them outside, but the queue time in the hospital is very long, which is also the longest time we stay in the hospital. "
One patient told reporters.
Yang Chen's family was also compelled to choose to quarantine themselves at home.
As early as January 26, he told reporters that there was no environment to quarantine patients at home.
"Two rooms, two patients, five people, how we are quarantined?"
Yang Chen bluntly expressed his concern: "There is no quarantine environment at our home, and I don't know when I will be infected.
I take care of my sick family at home, and I need to go out to buy food, which inevitably leads to more people being threatened by viruses. "
On the afternoon of February 3rd, when Yang Chen was interviewed by reporters again, her voice was a little weak: "I only know that my grandmother and I went to the hospital yesterday, and we have diagnosed inflammation of the lungs.
Grandpa is dying, and he hasn't been tested for nucleic acid yet. "
Tian Xiaoling, who lives in Shanghai, is even more upset. The two old people are quarantined at home and left unattended.
"Because the two old people are infected with the virus and there are no private cars at home, they have made countless calls to the community, and there is no car to send them to do nucleic acid testing."
Tian Xiaoling mentioned that because there are more people doing nucleic acid detection, they still need to queue up, which takes one day and one night.
"Even if I call 120 to send them to the hospital, how can they come back?
The designated hospitals are full. Where are the beds? “
"The basic procedure is to register, measure body temperature, measure blood oxygen concentration and record personal information first, and then call the number and see the attending doctor. After the doctor prescribes the medicine or the checklist, he will write a list and go to the pharmacy to take the medicine or do the examination.
After prescribing the medicine, you should wait in another line to take the medicine, and then find the nurse who is in charge of injection for infusion after dispensing the medicine. “
One patient told the report of our journal
Many doctors working in Tongji Hospital told reporters that many doctors were infected with COVID-19 in fever clinic.
Worried that if one's infection is transmitted to his family; it is also for the convenience of work. After work, the doctors in the fever clinic of our hospital concentrate on staying in the city express hotel opposite the hospital.
"Almost every one of us is exposed, but everyone is still facing up."
An oncologist told reporters.
What are the reasons for this problem?
A neurosurgeon at the AAA hospitals in the head said: "The first is the bed, and the compliant bed is far from enough; the second are materials, consumption is far greater than supply. "
As for the test kit, a doctor from Wuhan No.4 Hospital revealed that as long as the hospital is hospitalized, it will basically do nucleic acid test, and the patient can only be discharged from the hospital if the throat swab is negative twice.
However, some doctors have reported that it is very difficult for people around them to do nucleic acid testing.
"It's hard to test, it's not necessarily that the kit is not enough.
It may also be that there are not so many doctors to do it, they are too busy, or there is not so much machine space.
It may even be that there are not so many staff, but it may also be that there are not so many protective clothing, so there are no staff with proper protective equipments, and we can’t let these staff work without protection.
“The problem should be one link at a time. "
A senior emergency doctor at Peking Union Medical College Hospital thinks.

"People have to be hospitalized after testing, and the storage capacity is limited. People can only be tested when they are hospitalized, and they have to go through the process.
Our front line is very distressed, and we are caught in an infinite loop. “
However, some doctors believe that it is not necessarily the most important thing for patients with mild and moderate diseases to be diagnosed as coronavirus infection.
Its main problem is not anti-virus, but symptomatic treatment, and this symptom depends on its degree of light, medium or heavy.
If the symptoms are very mild, patients only need quarantine, drink plenty of water, properly use anti-virus and anti-infection drugs, keep sleeping and strengthen nutrition.
This virus can easily attach to invade the mucosal cells in the lungs.
"At present, hospitalization is mainly symptomatic treatment, allowing patients to survive the dangerous period, maintaining the stability of various functions, oxygen inhalation due to lack of oxygen, adding some infectious drugs and antiviral drugs to infected patients, and supplementing some electrolytes with incomplete electrolytes. Globulin supports therapy, and some anti-AIDS drugs such as Klebsiella can also be used, but the current clinical quantity of this drug is far from enough."
Another deputy chief doctor holds a similar view.
"Whether this disease is refractory depends on the basic condition of the patient, and young people can come over when they can; Secondary to the elderly, the anti-infection ability is poor; Very few children have this disease. "
A doctor working in a 3A hospital told the reporter that he was in quarantine at present. Recently, a colleague coughed and had a CT scan, and his lungs had virus-like changes. As a doctor who had been in close contact with this colleague, he also needed quarantine.
"Once CT shows virus pneumonia, 95% of them are infected with COVID-19.
Doctors are more likely to infect their colleagues if they are poisoned. After all, they are not completely quarantined. “
The doctor said.
However, his colleagues did not do nucleic acid testing.
On the one hand, it is because his colleagues have recovered almost at present, and they don't want to make a kit.
On the other hand, the sick doctor is worried about the risk of cross-infection caused by nucleic acid testing.
At present, the fever clinic collects oropharyngeal swabs for influenza and COVID-19 RT-PCR.
"The people who take the materials are also high-risk groups, which may be contagious. When they are not good at taking materials, they will cross-infect."
The aforementioned doctor told reporters.
"Wuhan requires a lot of people to do nucleic acid detection, and the kit may not be available.
Even if our doctors do nucleic acid detection by themselves, they can't do it if they want to, but only through the examination and approval of department leaders.
In addition, the disease is more evil, and even after it is cured, it will cross-infect.
The so-called “recovery”, is to achieve a balance.
Once this virus rises again, it may come again. “
The doctor said.
The winter, time and history of Wuhan will give the answer.

English content: Wuhan of regret: Gold prevention and control of how missed? - Nei.st https://nei.st/medium/china-new
English title: "Deleted" How Wuhan's prime prevention and control period was missed
原文標題: 【被删除】武汉之憾黄金防控期是如何错过的

English content:
“Li Pingping, who works in a designated hospital in Wuhan, tells the story of the medical personnel who fought against new pneumonia and spent a difficult night under the condition of shortage of materials and manpower.
After 13 hours of continuous consultation, Li Pingping also fell ill.
After that, due to lack of test kit, Li Pingping cannot be counted in diagnosed number.”


Dictation: Li Pingping, Medical PersonnelDesignated Hospital in Wuhan 
Time of Dictation: January 25, 2020

Before becoming the designated hospital

From January 20th, a week before I fell ill, I received and managed several suspected patients successively.
The first one was a 73-year-old male patient, who was admitted by outpatient to the hospital with poor appetite. The patient didn't eat at home for 5 days, and didn't have fever or cough.
I have a history of close contact with this patient, because he couldn't stand up when he came. I lift him to bed with several other doctors, nurses and family members.
I immediately arranged to draw blood and gave him chest CT. At that time, his condition was serious, which was a typical CT sign of viral lung. According to the latest diagnosis and treatment plan issued by the National Health Commission of People’s Republic of China at that time, he could be identified as a suspected case.
Because there was no available bed in the respiratory department, he waited until there was a bed in the respiratory department at night before turning around.
The second case was a woman who said she had abdominal pain.
She said she had abdominal pain, but it was actually a symptom of gastrointestinal indigestion.
The patient knows that she has a lung infection.
Before she came to me, she went to the respiratory department for treatment. After taking CT, the doctor gave her an admission certificate. As a result, because there was no bed, she wanted to come to our department.
Actually, she had a history of fever and cough for several days, but she didn't tell me when I asked about the history, and she didn't tell me until I checked her outpatient medical records and examination results.
There is also a patient transferred from ICU of our hospital, and the cause of jaundice needs to be investigated.
During his stay in hospital, he had fever and symptoms of lung infection, but after a week's reexamination, he did not improve significantly. The patient was later transferred to another designated hospital.
When receiving these three patients, I only wore a white coat, a two-layer surgical mask and an ordinary disposable hat for surgery without Level-3 protection.
At that time, our hospital was already in short supply, and only respiratory department, emergency department and intensive care department were equipped with Level-3 protection.
We had Level-2 protection.
On January 21, our hospital was notified to become a designated hospital.

The 1st night in the designated hospital
On the second day after receiving the transfer order, we emptied the whole hospital to treat patients with viral lung.
In the afternoon, the hospital gave us a meeting to talk about how to carry out Level-3 prevention.
However, under the condition that the hospital materials were not fully equipped at that time, it was difficult for all of us to do Level-3 protection.
On January 22, some departments of the hospital were transformed into infusion rooms, which gave a large number of outpatients infusion and observation.
An infusion room can hold about 8 people and can receive more than 50 patients at one time.
At 7:00PM, we started to receive patients.
At that time, the ward was not open yet, and a large number of patients poured in and stayed in the outpatient and infusion rooms.
On the night of the January 22, 200 patients came here successively. In order to give patients injections and infusions, the nurses worked in the assembly line and were exhausted
Some doctors and nurses, only wore the ordinary surgical masks with two layers and started receiving patients.
A father and grandmother, who probably didn't know that our place had been changed into a designated hospital, rushed here with their kid in their arms, saying that their kid had a fever of 40 degrees and wanted to be infused.
At that time, our wards were full of patients with viral lung. I was afraid that the three of them were infected with the virus, so I was anxious to drive them out quickly.
I said, we wouldn’t receive kids here. There were all viruses. You should go to pediatrics.
They said, the pediatrics building has been blocked, how can I go there.
Due to lack of guidance, no one told them that the pediatrics building has been blocked and where to go.
I also have a kid, and can fully understand their feelings. I want to take them there, but there are still lots of patients to be treated, I cannot leave.
After explaining the situation to them, they ran away quickly.
Lack of guidance boards, lack of guidance staff, patients sometimes went to the wrong places in hospitals.
For some patients, when doctors watched their films, they know that they are viral lungs, but they feel that they are not and others are, and they are afraid that others will walk around and infect them.

Because there were many patients, we were too busy. Nurses never stopped giving injections to patients, and there were no people to help us maintain order. Therefore, patients and their families were impatient after waiting for a long time.
That night, a nurse gave a patient an injection, and asked the patient to take the infusion bag or bottle to find a stool. The patient was dissatisfied and swearing, and asked the nurse to carry the infusion bag or bottle to his seat. Another colleague was afraid of the patient's noise, so he was led to the stool to appease him.

My colleagues and I noticed that the disease was in early January.
At that time, there was the file of the National Health and Family Planning Commission to check the unknown pneumonia in Wuhan.
Our hospital had a department director's proposal to set up a special quarantine ward.
Unfortunately, this opinion was not adopted in the end.
Clinical doctors were nervous and cautious, but at that time the hospital was short of materials.
If it’s not front-line department, there was no Level-3 protection for medical personnel. Front-line departments such as emergency department, respiratory department and ICU are also in short supply.
In order to saving, when we wear protective clothing, we will wear surgical quarantine gown outside, so that, even if the surgical gown is lost and the protective clothing can still be used.
For a time, one protective clothing and three nurses took turns to wear it. If one of them was a potential infected person, it would be very troublesome.
We don’t need money now, we only need materials to protect ourselves.
If the shortage of materials continues, the infected medical care will only increase, which will also affect the development of diagnosis and treatment.
In these days, we encountered with some inconvenience. 
At 10: 00 on January 23, Wuhan was locked down, and the buses in the city stopped, which made it inconvenient for many doctors to go to work.
Doctors are also potential infected people, so they are not suitable for walking on the road. Therefore, we contacted some hotels, which were not willing to let us stay.
Fortunately, in recent days, people with good intentions came to help us, and colleagues stayed in the hotel.
Some people had special difficulties. For example, a couple had to go to the front line, and the elderly couldn’t take care of their kids. The husband asked if he can take his wife's shift and let her take care of the kid at home.
The outside world donated some materials to Wuhan, but for some reason, my colleagues and I haven't got them yet.
The directors of some departments contacted the donated materials for the sake of the people managed by them.
Our director got us a batch, which can last for about a week, but other departments were not clear.
The director said, hold on, and wait for supplies to go to the battlefield.
Some patients fell out of the clinic, and their bodies were left untreated for some time.
Later, my colleagues who went to the scene told me that people from the funeral parlor arrived at the scene and said that this kind of corpse should be treated specially, and asked us to wrap the corpse by ourselves.
Some people on the Internet said that it was a rumor that the corpses cannot be treated in time, and I was very angry when I saw it.
This is not the case in normal times. When a patient declares death, we call the funeral parlor and the funeral parlor will handle it directly.
Some of the patients I contacted on that day were already dying when I saw them, and some of them were because their diseases developed rapidly and their oxygen saturation was only 40. These patients were respiratory failure and their oxygen saturation was not good.
Oxygen inhalation is useless. We need a ventilator. We couldn't take it in the intensive care unit. We didn't have a ventilator in our department.
Even if there was one, it would not be used if it was not a respiratory doctor or nurse without guidance and training before.
Without test kit, everything was stopped by “suspended case”.
Unexpectedly, I went to work for only one day under such circumstances, and I fell down.
On January 22, the first day of becoming a designated hospital, I started working at 7: 00 in the evening, and worked all night. At 8: 00 the next morning, I started to feel sore throat and chest tightness.
I had a rest at home that day, and I started to have fever and low fever from noon, which aroused my vigilance, so I went to a nearby hospital to see a doctor.
At that time, I had a fluke mentality, thinking that it was only respiratory infection, so I went to our hospital for CT, where the virus density was relatively high, but there was a risk of infection.
As a result, I got the examination report, and according to the CT results, I was also "got hit".
Now is the third day of my illness. I still have intermittent fever and fatigue, but I have no symptoms of chest tightness.
From my CT results, the infection focus is not big, it should be early stage.
It may be related to my frequent contact with patients, intense work and decreased resistance.
Now, I'm quarantined at home.
My mother cooked chicken soup for me every day and sent it to me by my husband.
If I wanted to go to the front line, I had to be quarantined from my family, because even if I was not ill, it was also a potential source of infection, and I was afraid of infecting them.
The child was sent away long ago. When I contacted and accepted the 73-year-old man, I showed him CT, which was a typical CT manifestation in the diagnostic criteria and knew that he was a suspected case.
After seeing him, I called my mother and asked her to take the baby away and live with her grandparents.
Now, my mother sent me some videos of kids every day to encourage me.
My kid could say: Mum, love you.
So lovely, I hoped I can be recovered earlier, and accompany with him.
My situation is not in the officially announced number of infected people.
According to the criteria of diagnosis and treatment at that time, it can only be confirmed as a confirmed case after reagent test.
I consulted in our hospital and another designated hospital, but I didn't get the chance to do reagent test.
Without the test results of the kit, there was no basis to say that you have been diagnosed. No matter what the situation was, it could only be considered as a suspect.
I didn't know if it is a work-related injury if I was really infected with this disease, but it couldn't be diagnosed. Many medical personnel should have the same confusion as me.
I didn't know how long the special situation would last.
Wuhan Xiaotangshan (referring to Wuhan Huoshenshan Hospital) is under construction, and materials were being transported to Wuhan.
Today, Wuhan informed that motor vehicles will not be able to hit the road from January 26.
There should be fewer patients, and it may end soon, and I hope it will end soon.
* The party information has fuzzy processing
Writtent by | Wen Lihong
