English content:
In the village at the junction of Wuhan and Ezhou, a car wIth Hubei-A of license plate traveled forward at the rainy night and was blocked by something.

Father got out of the car and came back with pale looking: someone put up a tombstone in the middle of the road.
"They are afraid that we escaped from Wuhan." father's voice was a little excited. "They don't want us to pass here."
From fear to worry to discrimination everywhere, Hubei people have experienced a psychological drift in the past week.
As “People's Daily” said: "Anti-epidemic" cannot be "fear of Hubei", and our only common enemy is COVID-19.
The good news is that this situation is slowly changing.
1. Hubei A, 4201 and Wuhan accent
On January 24, early in the morning of New Year's Eve, Guo Rui's family got into trouble in the parking lot of a village in Dali, Yunnan Province.
A young man came over and said that the license plate of Hubei A is not allowed to go out!
Guo Rui said, we don't drive out, we just see if there is any scratch.
The parking lot manager came to help explain that they had lived for a long time, so it doesn't matter.
The young man showed suspicion and said, "I want to report this matter to the village.".
More than half a month ago, Guo Rui's parents drove from Wuhan to Dali by car.
On January 21st, Guo Rui took a holiday at the Science Journal Magazine, and the next day, she flew to reunite with her parents.
At that time, the epidemic situation in Wuhan showed signs - the unit took temperature every day and called on everyone to wear masks - but the news of “city lockdown" was not announced until January 23.
According to the original plan, their family will spend the Spring Festival in Dali.
Back to the B&B, Guo Rui was taking a nap and vaguely heard the sound of quarreling.
When she woke up, her mother told her solemnly that the young man had reported to the village director.
The village director came to negotiate with the owner of the B&B, saying that the car from Hubei stopped at the entrance of the village, which would make tourists and locals react violently. We don't allow you to stay here.
Guo Rui's mother said, it’s ok to ask us to leave. There must be a normal procedure. Take our temperature at least."
The village director said that taking your temperature is a digression. Dali forbids you to stay any longer. Go to Lijiang or Xishuangbanna.
After a long time, Guo Rui's father walked to the parking lot and saw the young man again. He was questioning the administrator: Why didn't you let the owner of Hubei-A go?

Father was angry and said we leave right now.
After returning to B&B, they started to pack up luggage.
The manager of B&B asked them to stay for one night, it was Chinese New Year Eve.
Father said it’s OK. Don’t let other shout to you in the Chinese New Year Eve, there would be some troubles.
Guo Rui's family was on the way home.
Andy in Beijing also got into trouble because of "Hubei-A", and she hasn't been back to Wuhan in the past 6 months.
On January 27, she received a phone call from the local police station, saying that someone in the community reported and asked her to move the car.
She was surprised that the car was parked in the parking space, which would definitely not block anyone.
She was later told that the whistleblower only wanted to find out the owner of the car with license plate of Hubei-A.
She was very uncomfortable, and felt many pairs of eyes behind her, and her every move was being monitored.
In Lijiang, 55-year-old Mr. Chen and his wife came to the booked hotel, but they couldn't check in because of their Wuhan ID card starting with 4201.
The policeman came to mediate and asked them to go to the hospital for examination.
After issuing the health certificate, the policeman said, we can't force the hotel owner to receive you. You can only find a way by yourself.
Mr. Chen found a WeChat group, which is full of Hubei people stranded in Yunnan.
Some people in the group provide a hotel-style apartment, which costs more than RMB 200 per night to accommodate Hubei people.
He stayed in on January 26, and the next morning, the surrounding residents reported to the police, and the police rushed over again.
Seals were posted outside the hotel, the cordon was pulled up, and the police stood at the door.
At first, they were forbidden to order takeout, and the food problem could not be solved. After a long negotiation, the police reluctantly agreed to order takeout and send it to the front desk of the hotel.
In Hainan Province, Wuhan accent has become the sign of plague.
On January 20, that is, the day when Academician Zhong Nanshan said that there was "human-to-human infection" with COVID-19, Chen's family in Hankou flew from Wuhan to Haikou.
After leaving the airport, Xiao Chen's mother spoke to the driver in "Mandarin which she thought was still very standard".
As soon as the driver listened and said, are you from Wuhan?
There seem to be seriously ill there, then the driver opened the window.
Slowly, people started to seriously talk about Wuhan.
Xiao Chen and his mother were chatting in Wuhan dialect when they took a tour bus in the West Island scenic spot of Hainan.
Suddenly someone in the back row said angrily, "they are all from Wuhan!"
They fell silent.
On January 23, Wuhan was locked down, and the return flight was canceled.
After several considerations, Xiao Chen decided to take his family to Changsha first, thinking that it was really impossible, so he rented a car and went back.
At nine o'clock in the evening of Chinese New Year Eve, they arrived at Changsha Huanghua Airport.
But after staying in the hotel, the front desk was empty, and the shopkeeper expelled them on the phone.
Mother was unwilling and saw a man sitting in front of the hotel next door. She asked, can we stay here?
The man said, you are not from Wuhan, are you?
My mother said in "very nonstandard Mandarin" that I am from Wuhan.
The man said, that we don't accept, hurry to leave, otherwise I will leave.
After that, the man disappeared from the front desk and turned and ran upstairs.

2. The message is being updated
At this time in Wuhan, the news of the lockdown of the city has not yet spread to every corner.
At 9: 00 a.m. on January 23, Zhang Ze, the express man of Wuhan University, went downstairs and saw the landlord's door closed. He said to himself, "This grandpa used to open the door all day and asked me for water and electricity bills every day. Why is the door closed now?"

In the snack bar, people put on masks. After eating a bowl of Regan Noodles, he took out his mobile phone and saw that the crowd was saying: Wuhan has been locked down.
Before going upstairs, he went to the landlord's door and looked at it again. The door was locked. He realized that something was wrong. "The landlord ran away, he didn't even want money!"
At this time, the guy from the same hometown called and said that he ran away at 8 o'clock this morning, and the time was too tight to call Zhang Ze.
Under various signs, Zhang Ze made a decision to go home with another fellow villager in the afternoon.
When he packed his luggages, he only took 3 books with him, one of which was Foucault's “Courage to Tell the Truth”.
When come to the toll station out of Wuhan, the fellow villagers who took him on the road took a video and sent a circle of friends: Come on, Wuhan!
Zhang Ze felt absurd: people are running away, but they are still encouraging Wuhan.
On the afternoon of New Year's Day, January 25, Wuhan COVID-19 Prevention and Control Headquarters issued an announcement: starting from 00: 00 on January 26, the central city area will be subject to motor vehicle ban management.
Seeing that they couldn’t go back to Wuhan, Guo Rui's family, who just left Dali, planned to rush back to their hometown in Ezhou.
Parents' registered permanent residence is in Ezhou, where there is a suite. According to the infection data of epidemic situation, Ezhou was safer than Wuhan.
一家人开始联系各自在鄂州的朋友，朋友们说还没封城，私家车应该能进来。
The family began to contact their friends in Ezhou, and their friends said that private cars should be able to come in before the city was locked down.
A few hours later, they constantly received new messages: you may not be able to enter Ezhou.
Guo Rui wanted to verify the news online. In Weibo and WeChat official account, the news she saw was like fake news. Panic made her forget to visit the government official website.
Compared with Wuhan, which expressways are open easily, Ezhou has nowhere to find information.
The classmate sent her a screenshot, but she didn't understand the statement. It only said which high-speed ports can't enter Ezhou, but is Ezhou going to be locked down?
She suspected that mobile navigation was constantly changing with the updating of the prohibition order.
Before zero o’clock, they always followed the same road to Ezhou. After zero point one, the route disappeared on the map.
After trying several different routes, and all failed, they had to divert to Wuhan.
It's past zero o’clock. Can Wuhan be opened to traffic?
This was also unknown.
A few hours ago, the announcement in Wuhan was followed by another one: inform the owner of the prohibited motor vehicle 24 hours in advance by SMS, and the motor vehicle without SMS notification can pass.
Is the person receiving the text message allowed or forbidden?
Guo Rui read it several times then understood, her father didn't receive the text message, but he was worried that the ban would change again.
At 4 o'clock in the morning, they drove into Wuhan, and everything on the street was normal.
A few hours after they got home, the friend sent a WeChat, saying that after receiving the notice, Ezhou was completely locked down from 0: 00.
In fact, according to the official announcement, the traffic control time for expressways and ordinary highways in Ezhou was at 14:30 on January 25.。
But before that, no one in the family could find a formal and clear statement, and vague news was mixed with panic, which was constantly emitted to them.
At 4: 00PM on the January 25, Zhou Yang, a 36-year-old Wuhan native, also received the announcement of "No Motor Vehicles in Central City".
She called the community and said that her mother had kidney disease and she had to go to the hospital for dialysis every other day.
At present, we have not received instructions from superiors, the community staff said.
The phone hung up.
Two hours later, the community called her back again: This happened, but now dialysis in some hospitals is lagging behind, so you have to confirm it. Are you sure you want to do dialysis the day after tomorrow?
How can dialysis lag behind?
Zhou Yang had not received any notice from the hospital.
The dialysis team's phone was busy, and so was the doctor's phone.
If they couldn't get dialysis, the water and toxins in her mother's body couldn't be discharged. "The whole person is soaked in a poison tank.".
She walked around the room holding her mobile phone, and the owner WeChat group was discussing community car allocation. There were 500 families in the group, one car, and the car should be reserved for patients with fever.
My mother couldn't walk to the hospital, she emphasized over and over again in the interview phone that afternoon.
The hospital is one bus-stop away from her home, but her mother's body can only support herself to walk downstairs to the vegetable market.
After 4 years of dialysis, my mother lost 15 kg. When she came home after dialysis, she had to sleep for 2 hours before she could get up for lunch.
I am ready to go against orders, Zhou Yang said. If I get caught, it’s OK.
In the evening, the prohibition order added the premise of "SMS notification", and Zhou Yang did not receive the SMS.
Early in the next morning, she watched the private car on the street running as fast as ever.
On Chinese New Year's Eve, Chen's family, who was still wandering the streets of Changsha, realized that all hotels would not take them in.
They turned back to the airport, thinking of at least finding a place to stay.
After passing the police station near the airport, mother said, "If it doesn’t work, we'll call the police."
Xiao Chen stepped forward and asked the security guard on duty at the door. We really have no place to go. Can we stay here for one night?
The security guard opened the small window and listened. He only said that there was no stool in it and he could not sit.
Mother was very angry. You don't even have a stool in such a big place?
Security guard said, your thing, we also can't control, or there is an Internet cafe over there, you could go to the Internet cafe for one night?
They finally went back to the airport.
It was destined to be a long Chinese New Year's Eve. Xiao Chen put all his short sleeves on his body and wrapped his coat in a hurry to sleep on the stool at the airport.
The next day, Xiao Chen joined a WeChat group of "Changsha Back to Wuhan" and saw that someone had already returned to Wuhan from Changsha.
At this time, she realized that all the tickets on the ticketing system were gray when she bought the high-speed rail tickets from Changsha to Wuhan directly, but if she bought the tickets that stopped in Wuhan, she could still go home.
She immediately bought a ticket from Changsha to Lu'an, Anhui.
When getting on the bus, she asked the train attendant if they could get off at Wuhan Station.
The train attendant didn't say anything, just asked them to register.
The train will arrive at Wuhan Station in an hour and a half.
According to the radio, all passengers who want to get off at Wuhan Station will get off in a certain train.
Xiao Chen saw that the platform was empty and even the lights were turned off.
2 girls waved goodbye to the conductor happily, and the conductor waved to them happily.
Xiao Chen was also relaxed and returned to Wuhan. She was no longer afraid. "She was not liked outside.".
3. They were attacked by viruses and we were attacked by hostility
As early as the beginning of the trip, Guo Rui's family agreed to sleep at the toll station all the way instead of looking for a hotel, so as not to be expelled and rejected again.
Roughly speaking, the journey took 24 hours, plus staying overnight. They set off at 5:00PM on January 24 and could arrive in Hubei in the early morning of January 26.
Before leaving, they brought quilts, instant noodles and steamed flower rolls.
We don't bother anyone, father said all the way.
But the next night, tired driving made him sleep at the toll booth for the planned time.
Friends said before that Ezhou was locked down at 0:00, but they arrived at the border half an hour late.
Passing a toll booth,  father asked the staff, can we enter Ezhou?
The staff opened their boxes and checked them, saying yes.
Father asked where to go, and the other person answered, and followed the navigation.
However, the navigation led them to a narrow dirt road, crossing a village at the junction of Wuhan and Ezhou.
It began to rain, and the car travelled forward, and a fuzzy outline appeared ahead, as if something was standing there.
Father stopped the car and took a look, and when he came back, his face was very ugly: someone had set up a tombstone in the middle of the road.
"They are afraid that we escaped from Wuhan." father's voice was a little excited. "They don't want us to pass here."
Father wanted to try another way, and thought of a big road to go.
When they got to the big road, their car was stopped by a policeman again.
They explained the cause and effect, and the policeman said, no matter what, even if you missed, the expressway is no longer open to you.
My father took out his ID card and said that we were originally from Ezhou. What should we do if we want to go home?
The policeman said, go to the hotel and wait for news. When will Ezhou stop closing the city and when will you go in?
Father was wearing a mask, and the policeman also was wearing a mask. Father stepped forward and tried to explain again. The other party immediately said, Stay away from me.
In Luoyang, Henan Province, one province away, Li Yanqing, who just returned from Wuhan, received a strange phone call: "You don't go out, you won’t harm people."
He felt puzzled, and remembered the day before, when Wuhan was locked down, the county staff called him, asked how he was and how Wuhan was doing, and collected his address, ID number and mobile phone number.
He also received an excel form from his classmates, which contained all the information he registered that day - for the further strange phone calls, and he decided not to answer them all.
The scheduled dinner for fellow villagers and friends was also canceled.
Friends sent condolences to him, but always added a sentence at the end: "Don't go out."
Li Yanqing thought, this is always a little abandon.
In Maldives, Ms. Liu from Wuhan spent her 31st birthday there.
She and her girlfriend live in a "water house" for RMB 7,000 per day. The water house is built on the sea, and you can watch the sea blowing on the balcony.
At night, all the stars twinkle clearly above her head, and she wants to "stay here all her life".
4 days later, Wuhan was locked down, and the airlines company canceled their flight back to Wuhan, so they had to move to a "shabby hostel" in the central city.
At this time, direct flights from Maldives to China could only go to Guangzhou or Shanghai.
After they flew to Guangzhou, the receptionist at the hotel asked them to show their "seven-day health certificate".
Mrs Liu said, I have been away for 9 days.
The front desk said that this is the company policy, and I am also an employee.
They put on 3 or 4 masks and took a taxi to the hospital.
The receptionist heard that 2 Wuhan people were coming, and told them to stand far away, "it must be more than 2 meters".
After the receptionist and the leader called, they said, you have to go to the fever clinic.
Clearly there is no fever, why go to fever clinic?
Mrs. Liu returned to the hotel with her friends, but failed to call 110 or change the B&B. At 9:00PM, in the lobby of the hotel, Mrs. Liu began to cry.
Her crying finally attracted the managers from Huanggang and sent them to another hotel which is willing to accept Wuhan people.
The box is filled with a long bohemian dress, but the thickest one is a thin coat and cowboy trousers.
Mrs. Liu turned on the heating and stayed stuffy all night.
When they got up the next day, their faces flushed bright red.
Someone knocked at the door, and 3 health clinic members wearing yellow protective clothing came in and swept their faces with thermometers, showing 38℃.
The armpit was measured again, and the temperature was normal.
The guard said, don't get excited, don't be nervous.
Mrs Liu wanted to change to a room with a window, but the hotel staff did not show up and put a room card at their door.
There is also a bottle of disinfectant attached. "You disinfect it yourself!"
No one came to clean it.
The 2 ladies booked a room for 3 days, but they didn't know that they would have to stay here for the next 2 months?
Although the hotel is ordinary, it still costs RMB 300 per day.
In Hong'an, Hubei Province, Zhang Ze, the express man, finally returned to his hometown with his fellow villager's car.
On the 1st day of Chinese New Year, relatives called his mother to say Happy Chinese New Year, but said: Don't come to my house to greeting, especially Zhang Ze.
He strolled downtown, wearing a mask, but the street was empty.
In the evening, he sent us a WeChat:
"They were attacked by viruses, and when we came back from Wuhan, we were attacked by inexplicable hostility, which was too magical."
4. Chinese New Year's Eve in 2020
On January 21, Zhou Yang got the news that the hospital where her mother was doing dialysis was going to start receiving COVID-19 patients. That night, she was insomnia until 3:00 in the morning.
The next morning, the mother and daughter drove to the hospital before 7 o'clock.
Standing at the gate, mother said to her, you don't go in. You are still very young, I am old enough.
"I looked at my mother's back and she went in alone."
Speaking of this in the interview, Zhou Yang cried again.
Friends didn't get together, and couldn’t go out. Li Yanqing stayed in Luoyang's hometown to quarantine himself. He played games, the king of glory, Yin and Yang master every day, and also read Chernobyl. According to him, "It is very suitable and very hard."
More specifically, stay in his own room instead of at home.
On Chinese New Year's Eve, his parents walked into his room without wearing a mask.
He pushed them out of the door, locked the door, and shouted to the parents outside the door: "I won't open the door if you don't wear masks."
On Chinese New Year's Eve, Li Yanqing ate a bowl of dumplings filled with pork and leek in his room.
This year, he also missed the link of making dumplings with his parents.
At one o'clock in the morning of Chinese New Year's Eve, braving the heavy snow in Yunnan, Mr. Chen drove to a hostel in the suburb of Xiangyun County.
When the boss saw the health certificate he presented, he handled the check-in procedure quickly.
2 hours later, he was woken up by the constant knock on the door - his ID card entered the system when registering at the front desk, and the arriving police asked him to get up outside the door to register information.
After measuring the body temperature, the policeman stood 1 meter away from him, and looked back and said, it's better to take off the license plate of Hubei A.
On the 1st day of Chinese New Year, the first thing Mr. Chen did was to take off his license plate.
He contacted the trailer company, took the car to the 4S shop in Kunming, and then rented a car and rushed to Kunming.
"Am I really sick?"
After moving her luggage and getting on the bus in Yunnan, Guo Rui felt weak. Maybe it took too much effort to move things, but she thought, maybe she was really infected.
She looked up information on the Internet and found that infected people might not have fever. That’s why the villagers didn't take their temperature, so they decided there must be something wrong.
Why do we have to come to Yunnan?
When she set out, she didn't know that the city would be locked down, and she didn't know that the epidemic was serious. She just wanted to reunite the whole family.
Now, she can't help implying to herself: I am a potential virus carrier, and I am an unsafe person.
If I hadn't come to Yunnan, would my parents have had a Chinese New Year?
Before being kicked out, the village party secretary asked the owner of B&B that how many people lived here.
The owner said, 2 people.
No one dared to mention her existence.
She thought, I'm the one who caused everyone trouble.
When the car started, father's face became more gloomy.
Once upon every Chinese New Year, her family was a frequent visitor to Yunnan.
In the early years, tourism was developed well here, father discovered Dali.
Now Guo Rui thought that these feelings may be wishful thinking, and they were regarded as a trouble by the city.
If they took the initiative to find a hotel, they might be able to stay there, but father was afraid of being rejected again.
On the first night,  father held his breath and never spent the night in Yunnan.
Until 3: 00 in the morning, they arrived at the first toll station in Guizhou. The family covered with cotton-padded jackets and quilts and slept in the car for 3 hours.
That night is also Chinese New Year Eve. At this time in previous years, Guo Rui would receive endless New Year's greetings and red envelopes on mobile phone. There is nothing this year.
Almost zero o’clock, fireworks bursted into the sky.
She rolled down the window and looked at it. The fireworks were very loud.
"They base their happiness on the pain of Hubei people," said the father who was driving.
Mother turned her head to one side. "I don't like Yunnan anymore."
WeChat keeps pouring in on mobile phones, telling them not to come back, and the words "don't come back" are swiped.
Father received a phone call from a friend: We can't explain some things clearly, but you just don't want to go back to Wuhan.
要不我们别回了，有一回郭芮提议说，父亲如她所料地拒绝了：如果情况很糟糕，那就是给省外人添麻烦；如果没那么糟，我只想回家好好休息。
Asked us not to go back? Once Guo Rui suggested that her father refused as she expected: if the situation is very bad, it is to trouble outsiders in the province; If it's not that bad, I just want to go home and have a good rest.
She knew that her father was hurt in his heart and didn't want to continue wandering outside.
Worried about his father's fatigue driving, Guo Rui bought him a lot of refreshing chewing gum.
Along the way, the family played a game together: looking at the license plate in front and guessing what happened to the owner.
Seeing a Zhejiang-A, she asked her father why Zhejiang-A was on the road. Zhejiang-A was not Hubei-A.
Father said that Zhejiang's defense is tight, so it is estimated that people don't want to stay outside.
At 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning, an Hubei-A came to the front, and father said, this is the same person as us, all of whom are rejected.
*In the article, Mr. Chen, Zhang Ze, Xiao Chen, Ms. Liu and Andy are pseudonyms

English content:
Since the outbreak of the epidemic, it has been difficult for suspected patients to diagnose, see a doctor, quarantine and obtain effective information.
On February 2, the governor of Hubei Province said that he would try his best to speed up the detection of cases, and the Wuhan epidemic prevention and control department said that it would concentrate on isolating and treating suspected patients.
What is the effect of the new policy?
“Caijing” reporter interviewed patients, medical personnel, community service centers and volunteers for immediately

Article | “Caijing” Reporter  Liu Yiqing published from Wuhan, “Caijing” reporter: Ma Ling, Wang Bo, Zhou Yuan and Li Siyang
Edited by | Xie Lirong
On January 18, Chen Luming, a Wuhan native, was given a critically ill notice by the hospital, with "pneumonia" written on the list. At this time, few people knew that this "pneumonia" was the pneumonia caused by COVID-19, which is now ravaging Hubei and spreading all over the country.
On January 20, Chen Luming suffered from respiratory failure. After his condition deteriorated, he entered the ICU ward and died on January 24.
Until his death, Chen Luming did not wait for nucleic acid test.
Since the outbreak of COVID-19, many patients in Hubei Province have encountered many difficulties in seeking medical treatment, and nucleic acid test is one of them. Many suspected patients with COVID-19 have been unable to be diagnosed and hospitalized because they had not been arranged for nucleic acid test, and some patients had died before being diagnosed.
According to “Caijing” reporters in Wuhan and other places, the difficult problem of nucleic acid test almost has run through the whole outbreak.
The turning point appeared on the evening of February 2. Hubei Governor Wang Xiaodong emphasized that they should do their utmost to speed up the case test, enhance the test ability of medical institutions, give play to the role of third-party testing institutions, simplify the process of filling out forms, strengthen the distribution of test samples for inspection and the quality control of testing, ensure the supply of medical materials for testing institutions, and ensure that the test stocks are digested within 2 days, and be held accountable for failing to complete the tasks.
Also at that night, many patients received the news through different channels.
"I don't know what's going on, the doctor suddenly added a list, and then I can do nucleic acid test, free of charge, and basically don't have to line up!"
Li Xiaoxiong, a native of Wuhan, the family suddenly got good news in Wuhan No.7 Hospital.
At this time, it has been more than 10 days since her mother, who is the most seriously ill, developed symptoms of infection.
She immediately told this news to “Caijing” reporter, hoping to spread it to more people who are waiting hard.

Nucleic acid test is the key to the diagnosis of suspected patients with COVID-19. If nucleic acid test is spread, it means that a large number of patients with COVID-19 symptoms will be diagnosed and further admitted to hospital.
At the same time, the positive signal released on February 2 was that the Wuhan epidemic prevention and control department indicated that it would concentrate on isolating and treating "4 kinds of people" such as suspected patients, which also brought hope to many anxious people.
According to “Caijing” reporter in Wuhan, some patients were not satisfied with community work at present, some communities refused to arrange vehicles to send patients to hospitals, some hotels used for quarantine were not responsible for medical treatment, and the accommodation conditions were not ideal. Some patients could not get the latest news about testing and hospitalization in time through the community, and some false messages in the network and WeChat group made patients exhausted.
It is believed that centralized quarantine treatment could end the situation of "headless flies" and reduce the cross-infection.
On February 3, “Caijing” reporter learned in Wuhan that the announcement of centralized treatment by the government had just been issued, and some patients and community members said that they had not received it, and some community members expressed difficulty in the feasibility of centralized treatment, so how to implement it needed further observation.
“Caijing” reporters will continue to pay attention to the implementation of this policy.
First is the diagnosis: nucleic acid test is finally released
According to official data, by 6: 20 p.m. on February 3, there were 17,335 confirmed cases, 21,558 suspected cases, 361 deaths and 503 cured cases with COVID-19, in China.
In Hubei, where the epidemic broke out intensively, by 6: 00AM on February 3, 11,177 cases were confirmed, 350 cases died and 295 cases were cured.
Li Xiaoxiong was lucky.
At 10: 00PM on February 2, 3 members of Li Xiaoxiong's family finished nucleic acid test in Wuhan No.7 Hospital.
For her, the new problem was that it would take another 4 to 5 days to get the test results.
Li Xiaoxiong's symptoms are mild, but she has vomiting and asthma symptoms. Her mother's problems had become more serious, and her lungs had become white.
Without the results of nucleic acid test, doctors couldn't prescribe specific drugs to cure diseases, and could only prescribe some common drugs.
Previously, Wuhan No.7 Hospital only opened 100 indicators for nucleic acid test every day, and only those patients who were very critical could get the doctor's prescription for nucleic acid test.
Some patients didn't have the luck of Li Xiaoxiong. Both patient Li Yan and her husband were suspected patients. Li Yan told “Caijing” reporter on the evening of February 2 that she had just received the notice of doing nucleic acid test, but her husband who was also ill had not received it. If she was not admitted to hospital, she would have to go to the hospital for reexamination, blood collection and filming. She was worried that her husband would not survive the reexamination.

Yang Yang, a Wuhan native, had suspected symptoms of COVID-19. He had just finished nucleic acid test and was waiting for the results. "It would be nice if more people were tested earlier."

He told “Caijing” reporter.
Yang Yang's father died of "suspected COVID-19" on the 4th day of Chinese New Year, and failed to be diagnosed before his death.
On the morning of February 2, Li Bing took  mother to the People's Hospital of Ziyang Road, Wuhan, and finally got an opportunity for nucleic acid test.
Before that, Li Bing accompanied mother to many hospitals. Because of the shortage of nucleic acid test kits and beds, the hospital could only prescribe drugs and asked mother to observe in quarantine.
On the morning of February 3, at the press conference of the State Council to deal with the COVID-19 epidemic, Tian Yulong, a member of the Party Group and chief engineer of the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, said that there was no supply problem for nucleic acid test reagents in theory, but problems such as resumption of production had been encountered before.
By February 1, the daily output reached 773,000, which was 40 times of the number of suspected cases, and the production capacity was restored to 60%-70%.
However, Li Bing told “Caijing” reporter that the nurse said that even if someone was diagnosed, someone could not guarantee hospitalization, and the bed was very tight, which needed to be reserved for more serious patients. Li Bing's mother had not yet had difficulty breathing.
But Li Bing's doctor friend told her that her mother has been very old and has been exposed to at least 3 infected people. Young people could still carry it, but older people may not be able to carry it. It was best to stay in hospital.
Li Bing's mother has been suffering from fever, diarrhea and repeated vomiting.
She said that her classmate's uncle was also a suspected patient with COVID-19, and her friends have heard several cases of infection and death. She prayed that her mother could stay in hospital.
Many patients said that they were somewhat relieved after doing nucleic acid test, and they hoped to wait to hospitalization as soon as possible.
Some doctors and patients told “Caijing” reporter that even if the nucleic acid test showed "negative", it would not be safe, and there would be "false negative".
A doctor said that a patient had been tested 4 times before he was found to be "positive". Such a situation may be caused by unqualified nucleic acid test paper, or by problems during the testing process.
Some doctors told “Caijing” that the current testing procedure is to test negative at least twice, and ensure that the images and symptoms return to normal before the patients can go home and quarantine themselves for 2 weeks.
Second is traffic: Who will send patients to hospital?
After the outbreak of the epidemic, from January 23, Wuhan was "locked down", and all the traffic in the city, such as bus and taxi, etc., was stopped.
In order to solve the problem of inconvenience for citizens to travel, according to Circular No.8 issued by Wuhan New Pneumonia Prevention and Control Headquarters, every community in Wuhan should be equipped with 3-5 vehicles, which would be dispatched and used by community neighborhood committees.
In the last 2 days, “Caijing” reporters learned on the spot in Wuhan, showing that many communities have not taken up this responsibility.
On January 30, after repeated high fever for many days, Li Yan and her husband finally got chest X-ray CT in Wuhan Central Hospital, and the results were not optimistic. CT showed that both her and her husband had multiple patchy ground glass shadows in their lungs, which was the main symptom of this round of COVID-19.
Husband began to have dry cough and fever many days ago. 3 days ago, Li Yan had similar symptoms. They suspected that they had been infected with COVID-19.
At 2 o'clock in the afternoon on January 28, she and her husband walked for an hour and came to Wuhan Central Hospital, the nearest designated hospital.
"We called the community and wanted to find a car to send a ride, but the community's reply was that the suspected case could not be sent, fearing to infect the driver."
“Caijing” reporter called the staff in Haiyue community, Wuhan, where Li Yan lives. The staff said that the community vehicles are only used by residents without epidemic situation, and suspected patients infected with COVID-19 had special cars.
In order to find a car, Li Yan contacted 110, but the phone couldn't get through. Then Li Yan called 120 and emergency personnel of 120 told her that she could be cross infected if she went to hospital, so that she was hesitant. 2 days later, she had high fever, and she called 120 again and it couldn't get through.
She could only drag her sick body to the hospital on foot.
After arriving at the hospital, she couldn't register, and she and her husband walked for another hour to go home.
Many patients told “Caijing” reporter that there are many such cases, such as registration, waiting and seeing a doctor, which take as long as 6-8 hours. In addition, many patients are overwhelmed by walking.
The reporter found at the scene of the community service center that there was a steady stream of fever patients who called and asked to send a car to the hospital. On the morning of February 2, 3 batches of fever patients rushed to the community service center and asked for medical treatment.
Community staff said that the drivers of the community security motorcade did not have professional protective equipment at present, and did not have the ability to transport fever patients.
It was necessary to wait for calling 120, and some of them had even been scheduled in 2 days. Community staff also helped to ask 110. After hearing the specific situation, 110 said that they were too busy to come.
According to the reporter, at present, volunteers had undertaken a lot of work to pick up and drop off fever patients.
Since the outbreak began, a local volunteer in Wuhan has been carrying out transportation related to the epidemic, including transporting materials, helping residents to quarantine and transfer, and assisting in sending them to hospitals.
He told “Caijing” reporter that many volunteers in their volunteer group were willing to take fever patients to the hospital.
After sending the patients, they would disinfect the whole car and the whole body, and open the door to ventilate for half an hour by the river. "I don't understand why the community and the government can't do this," the volunteer said. "We can do it, why can't they do it?”
On the second day after the suspension of public transportation in Wuhan, Didi urgently set up an emergency motorcade, including community security motorcade and medical security motorcade. However, the number of drivers in the medical security motorcade was about 100, which could not meet the continuous demand for medical treatment.
Wuhan government also urgently dispatched 6,000 taxis to carry out traffic security work. However, according to the reporter's observation, there were few taxis running on Wuhan road at present, and occasionally there were a few, most of which come from the security convoys provided by Didi, Shouqi and other companies.
Third is treatment: How many problems can centralized treatment solve?
The liberalization of nucleic acid test has solved the problem of patients' diagnosis to a certain extent, and another core issue that has attracted much attention is the centralized treatment of patients with different levels.
At noon on February 2, the epidemic prevention and control department of Wuhan issued an announcement, in order to prevent cluster infection and cross infection, all districts must complete the centralized treatment and quarantine of the existing "4 kinds of personnel" before 12 noon on that day, and realize the "daily settlement" for newly added personnel.
The "4 kinds of personnel" refer to confirmed patients, suspected patients, fever patients who cannot rule out the possibility of infection, and close contacts of confirmed patients.
Suspected patients were no longer quarantined at home to prevent cluster infection, and the centralized treatment and quarantine places of "4 kinds of personnel" must be separated to prevent cross infection.
The policy calls for speeding up the setting up of hospitals, establishing quarantined areas and wards, requisitioning hotels, guest houses and idle factories, quickly setting up standby quarantined places and providing necessary living, disinfection and medical facilities.
For patients, it was really good news to implement centralized quarantine and treatment. Patients didn't have to find a car to go to the hospital like headless flies, or they could get certain treatment without reliable test and admission information.
For hospitals, the biggest role of centralized quarantine of the 4 kinds of people was to restore normal operation as much as possible.
A doctor in Wuhan said on the social network that other works in many hospitals were almost in a semi-stagnant state at present, because it was impossible to distinguish whether a patient is a suspected patient, and many normal operations could no longer be carried out, but people would not suffer from other diseases because of COVID-19. If they were not rescued for a long time, the contradiction between doctors and patients would be aroused.
For those "life-saving" operations that have to be performed, only the highest level of protection was required, resulting in extremely high cost of one operation.
The reality was that the beds for patients in COVID-19 were still in short supply.
A ward nurse at Liyuan Hospital, a designated hospital in Wuchang District, told “Caijing” reporter that the previous requirement was to quarantine patients, one person per ward, but due to the limited number of wards and too many patients, it has now become 2-3 patients who share one ward. "We require patients to wear masks for 24 hours a day to minimize the possibility of cross-infection."
At the same time, there were still a large number of patients with fever pouring into the hospital every day. The nurse said that most of the patients can't be registered, and even if they were registered, they may not be hospitalized.

At present, other wards of Liyuan Hospital were undergoing renovation, and more beds would be available soon, but we had to wait.
Some patients said that it was their hope to be admitted to Huoshenshan Hospital and Leishenshan hospital.
At present, Huoshenshan Hospital, with a total construction time of only 4 days, had been delivered and would provide 1,000 beds.
On the morning of the February 3, the person in charge of the hospital told CCTV that the pharmacy had been equipped with various first-aid medicines, albumin, insulin, interferon, etc.
“Caijing” reporter learned at Huoshenshan Hospital that the first batch of patients would be welcomed at Huoshenshan Hospital on the evening of February 3 at the earliest, but it would take at least 2-3 days to treat patients on a large scale.
Another good news that excites more patients was that from February 3, the army selected 1,400 medical personnel to undertake the medical treatment task in Wuhan Huoshenshan COVID-19 Pneumonia Specialized Hospital.
Many medical personnel had participated in the fight against SARS in Xiaotangshan Hospital and the fight against Ebola in Sierra Leone and Liberia, and had rich experience in treating infectious diseases.
At such an extraordinary moment, the efficiency of military management and action made ordinary people feel more at ease.
Although there were two specialized hospitals in Huoshenshan and Leishenshan, a doctor in Wuhan told “Caijing” reporter that it is necessary to do a good job of "ward backup" and continue to transform local hospitals into quarantined areas and wards, so that they could be put into use in time when the number of patients increased.
A number of doctors also told “Caijing” reporter that some patients were mild and had self-healing ability, so they should be quarantined in a centralized way, and a small number of medical personnel should be sent to give medicine (oral medication) in a centralized way, and they should be monitored in a centralized way. Once the condition changed rapidly, they could contact the designated hospital for medical treatment immediately.
At present, a community worker in Wuhan told “Caijing” reporter that he had not yet received the notice of "centralized quarantine", and he said that even if there was such a requirement, it would be difficult to meet it.
Many patients also said that they did not receive the notice of centralized treatment and quarantine.
"If we really want to concentrate on treatment and quarantine, who can meet the needs of so many residents and so much?
Where are there so many places to be quarantined? "
He asked.
This community covers 14,000 residents, and the street where the community is located covers 27 communities. If people are to be concentrated and quarantined, the streets need to be arranged uniformly.
The above-mentioned community staff said that during the epidemic, they received various policy requirements every day, but it was very feasible, such as sending masks to residents. "How can we send the masks that we don’t have at all?”
It even includes asking the other party to sign and receive when sending materials to the quarantined suspected patients. "We must avoid contact, how can we sign?”
In addition, in the implementation of "4 Concentrations", how to ensure the daily life of medical personnel and quarantined personnel was also a challenge that needs to be actively addressed.
Some people have appealed for launching various restaurants to make meals, ensuring catering and helping to reduce the impact of the epidemic on the catering industry; Some people suggest that the government should buy services from the society, such as catering guarantee services from Hema and Takeout, emergency travel dispatching services from Didi, and medical materials storage dispatching services from Jointow. The engineering work of emergency management should not be done by the government, and efficient dispatching is its core responsibility.
By 23: 00 on February 2, the utilization of beds in designated hospitals in Wuhan was: 7,332 used beds and 131 empty beds, which were still in short supply. Centralized quarantine treatment was a guarantee for patients who could not be admitted to hospital. “Caijing” reporter would continue to pay attention to how to implement this policy in Wuhan.
Patients were helpless, the community was got wrong, and resources were still to be coordinated
Community was the first link between government coordination and patients.
The role of community in this epidemic war was very critical.
In addition to arranging vehicles, the community also needed to cooperate with the government to convey epidemic prevention policies, hospital information and hotel accommodation to patients. However, some communities had not achieved satisfactory results.
"Now the work intensity of grassroots staff and medical staff is also very high, and patients, grassroots staff and medical staff are all under great pressure. This is the current situation in Wuhan.”
A friend with a COVID-19 told “Caijing” reporter, "But the news said that they asked us to contact the community immediately, if we need anything. You will find that we not only call the community, but also call various departments. There is no way to solve it.”
She said that because some communities did not fulfill their duty to timely transmit medical information to patients, many patients could only rely on the information on the Internet and WeChat group, for example which hospital opened new nucleic acid test and which hospital had beds, but many information were false.
Patient Liu Jiangfei saw the news of opening beds in Tongji China-France Hospital on the Internet before. He called and repeatedly confirmed that in order to get a bed, he made an appointment for 120, and there were 360 patients in front of him. He waited from night until 6 am the next day.
When I arrived at Caidian Campus of Tongji China-France Hospital, I was told that there was no bed. It was the security guard of the hospital who answered the phone and said that there was a bed.
"I was busy all night. I don't know how many fake news like this."
He said, "There are so many beds on the Internet. Every day, there are news of various hospitals and various beds. Patients are squeezing their heads and want to go in. Finally, they find that it is a rumor, and it is a big blow to patients."
Liu Jiangfei said that patients are either on their way to the hospital or waiting in line every day, so they can't have a good rest. Any information on the Internet may save lives, so try.
"What if, what if, what if you are lucky?"
There are also grievances for the community.
A few days ago, the community administrator informed Li Yan to take them to the hotel arranged by the government for the suspected patients that night, but Li Yan waited all night without news.
The next day, she was told that the hotel had been arranged, but there was no medical personnel, so she had to be quarantined in her own home.
“每天一个说法，说实话我也不是很相信社区了。”
"New information in every day, to be honest, I don't believe in the community very much.”
In the face of doubts, the staff of Haiyue community where Li Yan lives responded to the “Caijing” reporter. "The community does not specifically contact the hotel, it is the coordination of the higher authorities, and we just listen to the arrangement.”
The staff also reported that community work is not easy. Because of the panic caused by the epidemic, many people with common cold also came to the community to register, and the community should check them one by one.
"There are also some residents who said that they want to be quarantined yesterday. When the quarantine notice came down, the traffic control brigade came, and they didn't want to go.
We informed a resident yesterday and told him, but he changed his mind today and wanted to quarantine himself outside. "
Community staff said.
Liu Jiangfei had pregnant women, children and the elderly at home. The quarantine conditions were not good. He called the community. The community told him that children were not easy to infect and insisted that he be quarantined at home. He asked the community staff, "If there is infection, are you responsible for it?"
After that, the community indicated that it would try to get him to go to the hotel for quarantine.
Liu Jiangfei's friend told “Caijing” reporter that the environment in some hotels was not ideal, and the rooms were not disinfected. When eating, all the patients were crowded together to take food, which leads to the risk of cross infection. Patients could only contact the community, but the reply from the community was that the quarantine environment is not their responsibility.
Community work coordination was the chassis of the overall coordination plate in Wuhan epidemic area at present, and the optimization of community actual operation ability, responsibility and process needed to be put on the agenda.
On February 2, the central government held a working meeting of the leading group for dealing with pneumonia epidemic of COVID-19. The meeting held that after the outbreak, the state allocated manpower and material resources to give centralized support, but the shortage of medical resources in Hubei is still outstanding, and it is the top priority to ensure the needs of materials for prevention and control of the epidemic in Hubei Province, especially Wuhan City.
(Chen Luming, Li Bing, Li Yan and Liu Jiangfei are pseudonyms in the article; “Caijing” reporters Han Shulin and Wang Feng also contributed to this article)

Small micro-enterprise life-saving time
Zhang Xiaoyun interface News 3 days ago
 "Some people say th
English title: A life-saving moment for small and micro enterprises
原文標題: 小微企业的救命时刻

English content:
Originally written by   Yao Yuan   
 Real Story Plan     Today

The epidemic is threatening people's lives, and some industries are facing a crisis of survival.
Hotels closed, shopping malls closed, travel agencies withdrew, theater performances were canceled ... During this period, many small and medium-sized enterprises and self-employed households in China had no income and continued to lose money. 
For small and micro enterprises, this was another "war epidemic" of survival.
We could reduce the loss by 80%, if the epidemic situation was reported 2 days in advance


Oral Statement: Zhang Ji,  Owner of Restaurant, Shunyi District, Beijing      
Yesterday, several of our brothers who run restaurants made an appointment to have a drink.
Talking about this year's situation, we were all very silent.
It was too difficult. Spring Festival should be the busiest time for restaurants, but now we could only keep watch over our own closed stores.
Several of us were originally employees in Beijing, working as chefs in the same restaurant. After saving some money, we started our own businesses.
On January 19, I began to prepare dishes for the Spring Festival. More than 100 mandarin fish, more than 100 chickens and 3 truckloads of vegetables, worth RMB 150,000, were brought into the storeroom of the store.
From the Chinese New Year Eve to the 6th  day, 200 tables were booked in our hotel.
According to the situation in previous years, it was conservatively estimated that the daily turnover during the Spring Festival should not be less than RMB 40,000.
At noon of Chinese New Year Eve, I was watching TV in my office when the front desk received the first cancellation call.
The news channel reported that Beijing began to diagnose local COVID-19 cases one after another. My heart thumped and I had a bad feeling.
Sure enough, since noon, the contact number of the front desk had never been stopped, and over 95% of customers had canceled their reservation.
On the evening of Chinese New Year Eve, there were only 3 tables instead of the original 20 tables.
As soon as I saw that the situation was getting worse, no one dared to eat, so I took the initiative to call the rest of the customers to cancel.
I said that the epidemic situation was serious and the store did not dare to receive it. The other party was very understanding

On the afternoon of the 1st day of Chinese New Year, I took the initiative to close the door, sent my employees home, posted a circle of friends, and gave all the dishes prepared by the kitchen to friends and regular customers in the store free of charge.
Some people drove to my restaurant to pick them up, while others I drove to send them to others in person.
Compared with throwing these dishes away and letting my friends eat them, I was a little more comfortable psychologically.
On the morning of 3rd day of Chinese New Year, I drove to the restaurant and found that our street had become a "vegetable market".
The owners of other restaurants in the same street have taken out the food which they didn't need for the Chinese New Year to set up stalls.
Chicken, duck, fish and high-grade seafood were all sold at low prices.
I almost cried and I couldn’t bear to see more.
I didn’t sell dishes.
Frankly, with a loss of more than RMB 100,000 , how much can dishes be sold?
My staff were eager to go back home, so there was no need to leave them to accompany me to face the people coming and going on the street for thousands yuan.
I had calculated that it was worth RMB 150,000 of foods, the monthly rent of the store is RMB 40,000, plus the salaries and utilities of employees. Since January 24, I have lost at least RMB 200,000.
This time, the loss of catering industry is much more serious than that during “SARS”.
In 2003, I worked as a chef at Longcheng Restaurant in Shunyi, Beijing.
During the epidemic period, restaurants were forced to shut down for more than 2 months.
However, when the epidemic occurred in April and May in that year, the restaurant warehouse would not hoard a large amount of prepared foods, but only lost the daily rent and utilities, which was less than 1/10 of the loss. Later, we spent more than 3 months to make up for the loss.
This year's timing is too special. Even if the news of the epidemic situation was reported  2 days in advance, we could reduce the loss by at least 80%. .
Last year, my brother Dong Zi, who was drinking with me last night, invested RMB 3 million to open his own restaurant. Besides  RMB 1.5 million that he saved for many years, he mortgaged his house and borrowed RMB 1.5 million from the bank.
Originally, the restaurant had a promising future, but I didn't expect this big hit.
During the Spring Festival this year, he also lost more than RMB 200,000 to hoard goods. I didn't know how long he can't open the business. He was now facing huge debt pressure.
Their family of 4 persons lived in Beijing, 1 child in college and the other in elementary school.
Chatting with us, he cried, I could understand his pressure, and diners were facing the same crisis.
These days, I stayed in the office to watch the news every day.
I believe that with China's strength, we would be able to survive this difficult time, but it was a matter of time.
I only hoped that the epidemic will end as soon as possible, see the dawn as soon as possible, and we can resume normal life as soon as possible.

Strawberries were mature, but we couldn’t afford to picking.

Oral Statement: Liang Ying, Strawberry Grower, Dandong, Liaoning    
On the Chinese New Year Eve, at the dinner table, my brother expressed concern to his parents, and he foresaw that the Wuhan epidemic would affect the sales of strawberries at home.
On the 1st day of Chinese New Year, we picked a batch of strawberries from the ground and sent them to the sales outlets.
On the morning of the 2nd day of Chinese New Year, my brother received a phone call saying that no one was coming to deliver strawberries today. He contacted several responsible persons, and all of them said they could not accept them.
My hometown is in Dandong, Liaoning Province, where young adults aged between 30 and 50 have their own strawberry greenhouses.
Every harvest season, there were 3 or 4 trucks to collect strawberries every day, and the daily sales volume in our village was about 5,000 kg. On average, every household could earn more than RMB 20,000 per day.
Originally, the income during the Spring Festival accounted for 2/3 of the annual income of strawberry growers in Dandong.
This year, the wholesale price of strawberries near our home suddenly dropped from RMB 14 to RMB 2, and the family lost at least RMB 320,000. We hired pickers, and RMB 120 per day per person could hardly afford it.
The annual investment of RMB 400,000 in the 4 strawberry greenhouses in our home, together with the preparation for the harvest period from May to November, was in vain.
Strawberries in the 2 sheds of my neighbor's uncle's grew slowly. I planned to sell the first batch of fruits with the best quality during the Spring Festival, but I didn't expect to meet the epidemic, and I lost my money.
As far as I know, in Dandong, at least 1/3 of growers were facing such a situation.
It was expected that not only Dandong strawberries, but also agricultural and sideline products in China were facing the same problem.
On January 28, I wrote down the unsalable situation of strawberries in my home on the Weibo.
I have few fans in Weibo, and I usually only interacted with my classmates.
Amazingly, I received many comments from strange accounts one after another, leaving messages expressing their wishes to buy strawberries.
After discussing with my brother, I decided that instead of letting strawberries rot in the ground, it was better to sell them through the Internet.
Netizens were too enthusiastic.
Up to now, a total of 50 or 60 netizens have placed orders remotely, with sales of nearly RMB 10,000.
Although it was very small to recover the loss of my family, I was still very grateful to them.
Some netizens didn't receive express delivery in their areas, they specially added WeChat and told me to cheer for me.
It was really touching to receive the warmth from strangers. Everyone had their own lives on weekdays, but when disasters come, the distance between people becomes closer.
After the loss caused by the epidemic and inspired by enthusiastic netizens, my brother realized the risk of relying too much on a single sales channel, and we would try to open up online sales channels in the future.
This morning, I went to the shed.
The villagers coming and going on the road were wearing masks and working in an orderly way.
Although strawberries couldn’t be sold, everyone took good care of them as usual.
Maybe everyone was waiting for a chance to pick the strawberries.
I was going to pay the rent, but I didn't know when I can open yet.


Orally Stated by Sister Cai, Owner of Japanese Restaurant, Xiushui County, Jiujiang, Jiangxi    
I opened a Japanese restaurant in Xiushui County, Jiujiang, Jiangxi, only 300 kilometers away from Wuhan, Hubei.
On January 23, the day when Wuhan was locked down, my Japanese restaurant, nail shops and barber shops nearby spontaneously stopped opening.
The county town is too close to Wuhan, so few people ventured to walk in the streets.
On January 25, the Market Supervision Administration issued a notice requesting the catering units in the county to suspend business completely.
Since closing the door, I had not earned a penny during this Spring Festival, and the cost of raw materials of RMB 4 or 5 thousand that I hoarded in the store before Spring Festival had not been recovered.
I was going to pay the rent next month, but I didn't know when I can open yet.
In small county towns, the small catering industry is mostly off-season all the year round. Usually, most of them could only earn RMB 2-3 thousand per month in rent cost. We could earn enough food and clothing every month and be satisfied with our daily life.
Spring Festival, winter and summer vacation were the peak seasons for business.
In previous years, from the Chinese New Year Eve to the 7th day of Chinese New Year, the average daily turnover in our store was RMB 6-7 thousand, and when it was good, we could earn RMB 1000. My friend opened a milk tea shop for more than 10 years, and the daily turnover in the store could be more than RMB 3,000.
After the outbreak, he nearly collapsed.
Before Chinese New Year, he hoarded high-grade out-of-season fruits, such as dragon fruit, mango, kiwifruit, etc., which could not be sold, so he had to keep them and eat them slowly.
The day before yesterday, he came to my house to get a mask, and when he talked about business, he was oppressed in his heart.
Natural and man-made disasters, during this period, everyone was too difficult, like those who were doing small business, who we can blame?
We were not like those who have fixed salaries.
Now staying at home alone, I was worried about my future business every day.
It could be opened after a period of time. In the aftereffect of the pneumonia epidemic, how long would it take for the store business to improve?
How long did it take for the passenger flow to return to the normal level?
If I missed this year's Spring Festival revenue period, can my further income in this year support me to the next Spring Festival?
If this shop couldn't go on, maybe I could only work in a big city.
I was not young. How could I compete with the boys and girls in their teens and early 20?
A few days ago, I tried to communicate with the landlord, hoping that the store rent could be appropriately reduced during the period of business closure.
She didn't reply to me, so I thought, forget it.
I knew that she also has a loan to pay back. In the face of this year's catastrophe, everyone had difficulties.


“Compared with the project being stopped, the performance risk of hundreds of people was even more terrible/”

Orally Stated by: Zheng Yitong,        Employee, Performance Company in Hebei Province  
Our company mainly accepted some foreign artists to perform in China, such as concerts, song and dance dramas and so on.
The size of the company was small, and there were only a dozen projects a year.
It was originally planned to have 2 performances in March and April this year. However, in recent years, we had received notifications from various provinces and could only cancel them temporarily.
Recently, we were busy changing schedules with actors and talking about losses with theaters every day.
I'm almost thinking about changing jobs now
In fact, I had just entered the industry for 1 year, and I really liked this job, but the economic situation faced by the industry really made me have to think carefully.
This year, we had a project, originally scheduled to invite Italian artists to perform from the 1st day to the 7th day of Chinese New Year.
On Chinese New Year Eve, the actor was going to board the plane from Italy, and my colleague arrived at the Capital Airport early to pick up. As a result, he received a temporary notice from the theater saying that the performance was canceled.
My colleagues and I panicked and contacted all parties urgently. Fortunately, we explained the situation to each other before the actors boarded the plane.
The performance went bad, and when we were disappointed, we were more thankful.
Since the Chinese New Year Eve, the epidemic has become more and more serious. Fortunately, the government stopped it in time, otherwise we couldn't really afford the performance risk of hundreds of people.
Our original trip was from Beijing to the northeast and then to Jiangsu.
In case we really followed this path, we couldn't be responsible for the health and safety of foreign actors.
There is a friend in the industry group. More than 200 actors in the Yunnan Song and Dance Theater had worked hard to rehearse the program for more than 2 months. The original plan was to go to Shenzhen bright farm for a 20-day performance. On the first day of Chinese New Year, they were notified to cancel the performance and evacuated to Kunming urgently. The whole project suffered heavy losses.
The national performance market in March and April must be blank.
At present, we hadn't received the notice after April, so we hadn't had courage to push off the original project.
It was estimated that in the next half year, all the performers in the performance industry would have no job. We laughed at ourselves in the group every day, and we could only hope that the epidemic situation can be controlled as soon as possible.
The salary of the tourism industry had dropped to RMB 2000, and the tour guide has zero income

Orally Stated by: Da Niu, Project Manager, Travel Agency in Hunan Province      
During the Spring Festival this year, all travel agencies were facing losses, and thousands of employees were unemployed.
I am in charge of some outbound travel business in a large travel agency in Hunan Province.
On January 24, Chinese New Year Eve, we received an urgent notice issued by the General Office of the Ministry of Culture and Tourism, requesting national travel agencies and online travel enterprises to suspend the operation of team travel products.
It took us a whole week to return the passenger's order and negotiate with overseas airlines and hotels to cancel the contract.
For domestic tour, according to the requirements of relevant departments, railway, civil aviation and hotel support refund, and we would also refund all the expenses to passengers.
Overseas travel products involve different countries and policies, and the situation is complicated.
Generally speaking, overseas airlines and hotels will not refund money to travel agencies because of China's special circumstances.
According to Article 67 of the “Tourism Law”, some losses that have already occurred, such as airfare and hotel expenses, needed to be borne by passengers together with us.
After this ordeal, there was a loss of RMB millions.
The basic salary of tourism industry was implemented according to the minimum wage standard of every city, and its performance accounted for a large part.
During the Spring Festival this year, the monthly income of more than 1,000 employees in our travel agency was only RMB 2,000, and more than 100 tour guides in the front line were in a state of zero income.
The industrial chain of tourism is very long, in which the capital flow in one ring is interrupted, and the whole line will be interrupted.
Not only the employees of our travel agencies, but also the hotels, scenic spots, aviation, motorcades and service industries have low thresholds and many jobs, and some practitioners will lose their jobs, resulting in serious economic losses.
It is conservatively estimated that we may not start business normally until July and August.
Tourism is an industry that relies heavily on the state of the national economy. Only when people have enough food and clothing and spare funds will they consider traveling and having fun.
This time, the recovery period of tourism will only be longer than that of other industries.
Some colleagues joked that no one hopes world peace and good weather more than the tourism industry.
I joined the industry in 2008 and have been in business for 12 years, which is the biggest setback for the tourism industry since I joined the industry.
Compared with the SARS period, today's tourism industry has expanded by 1 or 2 times, with more employees and a larger number of unemployed people. Many small and medium-sized private travel agencies may not survive this level.
Many friends around me were considering changing jobs and posts.
In the first half of this year, tour guides must have lost their jobs, and many of them are still facing the pressure of car loans and mortgage loans. Some friends have started to find ways to find jobs in factories in Shenzhen, or consider going to overseas enterprises to make a living.
There is a saying that HR declares unemployment in other industries, while CCTV news directly declares our unemployment in tourists.
I hope that after the epidemic, the state can introduce relevant policies to support and guide the rehabilitation of tourism, and help front-line tour guides survive.
I know a tour guide leader of Thailand. He and his colleagues spontaneously raised funds to buy 80 boxes of medical masks. On January 30, they personally shipped the materials back to China from Thailand and sent them directly to Wuhan at the airport.
While future was still uncertain, we were still concerned about the epidemic areas and tried our best to help Wuhan people tide over the difficulties.
I am very proud of being a member of the tourism industry.

* At the request of the interviewee, some of the article are pseudonyms.

Written by | Yao Yuan

English content:
The Economic Observer Network  Reporter  Chen Yueqing
On the afternoon of February 10, Liang, a 70-year-old suspected COVID-19 patient, jumped to his death in Guangdian Jiangwan New Town Community, Qiaokou District, Wuhan City.
Liang Xin, a son of Liang, told the Economic Observer Network that his father jumped from the balcony of his home on the 9th floor at 14: 57 on February 10 and died on the spot.
About 20 minutes later, 110, 120 and forensic doctors arrived at the scene.
After forensic identification, Liang's death was not homicide.
Liang Xin revealed that because both parents were suspected to be infected with COVID-19, he did not live with his parents, and was quarantined from his home in Hanyang District, taking care of 2 children.
When his father jumped off the building, only his mother was present, leaving only one sentence to his mother, "I don't want to bring trouble to you", and then he turned down with his hands on the railing.

Patient with severe uremia
Liang Xin told Economic Observer Network that his father has been suffering from uremia for 5 years and has been undergoing dialysis treatment in Zhongshan Hospital in Qiaokou District.
On January 27, Liang had fever when he was undergoing dialysis in Zhongshan Hospital, Hubei Province. He suspected that he might be infected by surrounding patients during the hospital treatment, so he had an examination in the hospital fever clinic.
The CT results showed that Liang's lungs had patchy blur, infection or a little pulmonary edema, hardening of aorta and coronary artery, and atrophy of both kidneys.
The doctor of Zhongshan Hospital told Liang Xin that because his father was suspected to be infected with COVID-19, the hospital no longer gave him dialysis and suggested going to Pu'ai Hospital.
6 days later, after many twists and turns, father had a dialysis in Pu'ai Hospital, but was told that he had to be diagnosed as COVID-19 before he could continue treatment in Pu'ai Hospital.
Because the community has been unable to arrange nucleic acid test, this became the last dialysis for father.
By February 10, father died, and father, who needed dialysis 3 times a week, had not had dialysis for 8 days.
"My father is a patient with severe uremia. If he can't do dialysis in time, the water in his body can't be discharged."
Liang Xin said that his father had been unable to eat for 7 days, with diarrhea and dying.
"There is no problem for ordinary patients to be quarantined at home for 1-2 weeks, but severe uremia is not an ordinary patient. If you can't do dialysis, you will die!"
After Liang Xin reported his father's illness to the community and street, and hoped to deal with it urgently, but the response was, "Suspected cases can only be quarantined at home" and "in the process".
Liang Xin repeatedly called the mayor's hotline, and the staff told him that his father's situation had been accepted, so please wait patiently.

Didn't get the opportunity to receive nucleic acid testing
On February 9, the day before Liang jumped off the building, the community informed Liang Xin's brother to take his father to Gutian Street Health Service Station for nucleic acid testing.
When they arrived, the community worker said that the doctor who had tested had been off work and would come back at 8:30 tomorrow morning.
On February 10, Liang Xin's father and mother waited at the entrance of Gutian Street Community Service Station 15 minutes earlier. "My dad was quite happy at that time.".
At the appointed 9:30, no staff was seen at the scene. Liang Xin called the community staff to inquire about the situation. The other party said that the community had already arranged it, but suddenly found that there was no throat swab and no doctor to do the test, so that they could continue to wait at Gutian Street Community Service Station.
"My dad haven’t eaten for a week, and he was restless in the community service station, and incontinence was happening."
Knowing that the 2 old people couldn't wait in the community, Liang Xin called again to ask the community for urgent treatment, and the community said that they could take the number first and go home.
By about 3:00 pm, Liang still couldn't wait for the news that the community could arrange nucleic acid test.
At 9: 00 pm on February 10, Liang's body was transported away by special car.
An hour later, his wife, who was also suspected with COVID-19, was admitted to Puren Hospital.
Liang Xin denied that it was "in order to exchange his wife's hope for a dead end" that Liang had jumped from the building.
He told Economic Observer Network that his father was in a critical condition with uremia. He just didn't want to drag down his family, and then he died in despair.
Xu Ting (a pseudonym), a property officer in the community, told the reporter that "no hospital is willing to accept the elderly have uremia and need dialysis.
On the other hand, because the beds in hospitals are tight, it has not been possible to arrange nucleic acid testing and send a car to send the elderly to the hospital, which leads to the elderly dying. “
This article has been certified as "original" and is written by Economic Observer. Visit yuanben.io to inquire [5H1CGWAW] for authorization information.
